On arrival at the Golden Steer, you may question yourself. The exterior is sketchy, it seems as if you are far from the glamorous Strip, and nearby Circus Circus looms, questioning your decision with its white pillars of 1970's hotel blocks. You walk in and things still don't seem right at the bar. Your barender is distant, demanding; you can't transfer to your table. It seems this is awkward.

However, you steel yourself, saying, "I made the right call. The fancy overpriced places on the Strip have nothing on here, this is Old Vegas, and Frank was right. If they were trading on name alone, the Steer would be gone. I have faith." And you would be right.

As you're led into the main dining room with your date -- or, as with me, my cousin -- you would be wholly validated. The world opens, angels sing, tuxedoed waiters do their thing, and all is right in an onomatopoeic universe where quality is rare and the Steak is too, capital 's' intended. Enjoy it.

Do not question your decision. From the moment you set down in your red vinyl banquette, your waiter treats you as if it is 1958 and the Steer just opened. Charm and discipline exude in equal measure as the oiled wood and red banquettes simultaneously place you on display for all to see and sequester your conversation in privacy unheard of in the modern era. It's a lovely experience.

If you're an old-school aficionado of the steakhouse as I am, you should convince your partner to order one of the most difficult of "old cuts" of steak to find -- Chateaubriand for two. This extra-thick cut of the tenderloin is sliced tableside and accompanied by wonderfully crisp-tender carrots, asparagus, and broccoli with Bearnaise and Hollandaise sauces that put the 50's to shame. The vegetables and sauces were excellent and worth the wait. The steak was out of this world good, perfect doneness and a complete delight. My cousin and I opted to add a twice-baked potato with each of us having half. It was a good decision, but nothing special.

We skipped dessert as we were quite full but enjoyed our experience immensely. As we were there early in the evening, our waiter guided my cousin around to some of the named tables and pointed out how they used to enjoy their orders and experiences. She and I sat at Oscar Goodman's table, which was fitting for our evening, and enjoyed the history and charm of the staff immensely. I wish more places like this existed in the world; but if they did, they wouldn't be as special, would they?

Thank you, and I will certainly be back when in town. Cheers!

One of my fave restaurants in Vegas. Great food especially the table side options. Great service by real pro's. And the greatest hostess ever, who is beyond helpful Rika Cooper.  Just a great all around experience

I finally got to the Golden Steer last night, and it was simultaneously more and less than what I expected/hoped for. 

From the minute you walk in the, the odd juxtaposition of a nice steakhouse in a shitty strip mall makes it self known. Two of the signs on the doorway - "PROPER ATTIRE REQUIRED" & "RESTROOMS ARE FOR CUSTOMERS ONLY" are so rarely seen together. However, once you're inside the double entry-way, you have no idea you're on in a rundown plaza on the wrong side of Sahara. There's a very nice looking bar/lounge area immediately at the entrance, and the maitre'd is to the right. We had reservations, just to be safe (I know, it's only Thursday), and were seated immediately. (The Marilyn Monroe booth, if it matters). The decor is nice, no doubt about it, and it pulls off that old steakhouse vibe very well, without feeling phony or pretentious. I was actually quite skeptical on this, but there were no disappointments there. Our waiter, who was a younger guy, and not the old dude everyone talks about, was cordial enough, but definitely didn't do anything amazing. On to the food...

Appetizers:
Toasted Ravioli - As Gordon H told me "Not gourmet by any means, but I love them." And that's what went through my head as I ate them. Good stuff, but you're not gonna confuse it for a fancy dish.

Soup/salad:
We skipped. The guy at the booth next to us ordered the Caeser though, and it looked good.

Entree: 
8oz Petit Filet: My guest had this, and she proclaimed it easily better than the bone-in filet at Joe's, but not better than Joe's ribeye. This really surprised me to hear, but I didn't taste it, so I can't confirm/disconfirm. 

20oz? Ribeye: Pretty good, but not great.. I didn't get to finish it, so maybe it could've deserved better. Don't get me wrong, I wouldn't kick it out of bed, but it doesn't stack up to the competition IMO.

Sides:
Twice-baked potato: Con bacon. My fucking lady friend said that it was good. I think it was too, but I couldn't compare. 
Creamed spinach: Not great. Sweet & too creamy, in both of our opinions. Definitely outdone by Joe's & Del Frisco's here.
Onion rings: We both saw the onion rings, prominently displayed on the menu, and hoped that they were some extra special dish. They even had an aura emanating from them upon arrival, but ultimately they were just above-average beer-battered rings. 

Desert:
Bananas Foster: The fucking business. Flambéed table-side, as it should be. Our man with the frying pan had some liquor ignition issues, so he had to run to the back and start fresh, but the 2nd take went just fine. And the dish was well worth the wait. My FLF said it was definitely amongst the best she's had. I really enjoyed it, but I haven't had enough others to compare. 

Overall, I wouldn't rush back here for the steaks. There was a lot of seafood on the menu, which may be excellent for all I know. I will be returning to try the chicken/veal parmigiana, and definitely for deserts. Cool place though, and if I wasn't aware of other places I liked better, I'd probably come here a helluva lot more often.

Wow! This is by far the BEST meal that I've ever had in Vegas. It made me regret spending $70 per person at Bacchanal Buffet in Caesar's the night before,  when I could've just come here for a higher quality meal. Everything was great, from the food to the service.  The Caesar's salad is made right at your table -- something that no other restaurant will do anymore because of health codes, but since the Golden Steer is the oldest restaurant in Vegas, it was grandfathered in. Freshly made Caesar salad is amazing and you can really taste the quality.  We started with the Seafood Platter and the King crab legs were so fresh and sweet that we didn't even need condiments. I got the filet and lobster combination and that came with a 16oz lobster!  I'm a huge seafood snob, and the lobster was clearly fresh and so succulent.  We ended with the creme Brule, which was pretty typical. Aside from the fresh and high quality seafood, I also loved how iconic the restaurant is.  We sat in Joe DiMaggio's personal booth, which is next to Clint Eastwood's booth and across from Marilyn Monroe's. It was also across the way from the rat pack's booth-- they used to come to the golden steer for drinks and food before their shows.  Very cool!  It was really neat to be in such a historic and iconic restaurant.  If you have the time and the funds, this place is definitely worth the experience. The host Mark and our server Tommy were splendid and ensured that we had a perfect dining experience. I will be returning!

I don't know how I originally found this place, because the outside looks like a location in an episode of "COPS". The inside is great! It let's you peek into the rat pack era, without the fabrication. 

This was my third trip to Golden Steer.  I Started with a Dirty Martini which was very good. As a tradition, I ordered the Oysters on the half, which were fresh but less tasty then previous dinners. The plump shrimp cocktail made up for the oysters. I ordered the bone in ribeye (usually my favorite cut), but also had some of the wifes filet. I would do the filet here. Both were seasoned well. The sides (creamed spinich, wild rice) were just so so. 

The service was excellent, like each visit. I most like this place for the atmosphere, steak and service, but rate it 4 overall.  The strip mall location doesn't fit today's vegas. (to be fair, they cant move it. Its the oldest steakhouse in vegas).  But if you don't want that manufactured, trying to look old school steakhouse, look past the exterior and try it.

It's my second time going to this restaurant and so far so good. I love the history of this place and I've always enjoyed my dinner, drinks, and our server. I came with a big group and had a great time. Although my steak got switched with another person, so it was a little under cooked, i still enjoyed my experience. Great ambiance for an intimate dinner date or friends.

Went here for our 2 year Anniversary. 
Everything was great. They were pretty busy which I think made service a little slow. 
It is pricey. I want to go back and try the ribeye.

We're steak lovers and after reading all the great reviews, my girlfriend and I wanted to try the Golden Steer so we dined here last night for my birthday. My girlfriend had Caesar's Salad (tell them if you don't want anchovy paste in your salad) and I had the French onion soup -- both were excellent.  For dinner, we shared the 16 oz. NY Strip and lobster tail combination with a HUGE baked potato. For dessert, the waiters put a sparkler candle in our tiramisu and sang happy birthday at our table! (We made reservations on opentable.com and indicated a birthday celebration.) All the food was incredibly good and the wait staff was very attentive and friendly! We enjoyed dining here very much and will be back!

Congratulations golden steer on starting my yelp career! Never felt the need to write a review on any of my experiences good or bad. That is until I took my fiancé here for his 30th birthday dinner on 8/14/2015.

Food was okay, had the NY Strip and the ginormous lobster tail and even bigger baked potato. Combo meal came with soup or salad and veggies. Selected asparagus and clam chowder... Blah... (I'm from New England so I'm hard to impress with chowder). Good ,but nothing to rave about for any of the items definitely will not dream of eating anything I ordered. 

Now onto my terrible experience.
We arrived around 8 pm without reservations, which wasn't an issue, and were seated right away. Great so far. Restaurant was quite empty for a Friday night. Ambiance was lovely, very old Vegas. Nice. Snuck to the "bathroom" to set up a birthday surprise for my love. Hostess told me it is complementary and she would hook us up. Still going Great. Now here's were the ship starts to sink. Quickly. Waiter took our order. TWO lobster and steak dinners. TWO steaks ordered differently. Waiter comes out with one soup. Sorry sir we ordered two. No problem, he grabbed another promptly. Ate our "blazay" chowder just in time to receive our main course. ONE meal arrived and was placed in front of my fiancé. Surely mine was next. Nope I was handed an empty plate and utensils. "I'm sorry sir I ordered one as well". Blank stare. He left to figure out the problem. The man who placed our order came over and said he thought we were gonna share and he apologizes. (Mind you we ordered a well done steak and a med well steak, don't c how the chef would pull that off). Still no big deal things happen right? He told me it would take only 15 min or so to fire it up. Cool. Birthday boy offered to wait for my food as well. Cold lobster? No enjoy your food babe I'll wait. 20 minutes later no food! 30 minutes later my food arrived. Did I mention the restaurant was not packed? To bad my fiancé was full and done with his plate. So we ate two separate meals. By this time im a tad bit annoyed. Oh yea when my food came out they forgot my veggies and my lobster was over freakin cooked and my steak was well done!!! Whatever just bring on the damn cake. While eating I seen others celebrate their birthday with cake being brought out with sparklers and a cheerful hostess singing. Sweet. I wrapped up my plate as I was over it (still hadn't received my veggies, just a plate of meat) . The hostess comes over with an UNLIT slice of cake (there was a candle in it just wasn't lit) wtf? She places the cake down and said let me check on your veggies I'll be right back!!! Are u freakin kidding me? F$&& the veggies lady! Yay surprise happy bday bae . We sat there awkwardly with an unlit cake for 5 min or so until a different waiter came and asked if we needed anything ... Umm yea a birthday celebration would be nice. I told him the hostess ran off and never came back. He giggled and said I can light it. I wasn't amused. He lit the candle and stood there.AKWARD. I sang to him alone. Never again. By this time I was livid. He said I'm sorry about the confusion but I'm sure the food was good? What? Are u kidding me. No manager no compensation no anything. He proceeded to bring me the check with a smack in the face when he charged me 10 bucks for two glasses of water!!! 300 bucks for two dinners ,two waters and a side of disappointment. Thanks for ruining his birthday dinner Golden Steer. 

You get one star simply because my fiancés meal was correct and tasted fine.

Not too happy with this place.  We went in to celebrate Fathers Day.  Although the food was pretty good (No where near worth the $!) the service was hands down the worst ever.  First off, the staff seemed irritated to be there, including the Bartender and Server. When we first came in we approached the bar and asked if we could sit and have our meal there, the bartender rudely replied that we could but the service would be extremely slow, then walked away.  We sat there for about 15 minutes while she did dishes and prepared 3 drinks before she bothered giving us a menu.  We decided to wait for a table instead. It took 30 minutes before our server came over to take our order.  We watched other tables being sat and orders taken while we sat and watched our server chat it up with the rest of his section. FINALLY I ordered the $40 Filet and a 12$ ceasar salad (it wasn't good at all) that was to be "prepared table side".  Someone from the back just came and dropped it off at the table.  I asked later why everyone else that ordered it had it prepared in front of them and I didn't. He said only at tables that order 2 or more salads.  Even though I watched the woman at the table next to mine order 1 salad for her table and get it prepared table side. We were younger than most of the crowd in there, but definitely were there to spend money. Hands down the worst service I've ever had.

Simply stated this is probably the best steak house experience you can have in Las Vegas. 

You can get a good steak and good service in a lot of places in Las Vegas. But the difference here is the experience. Of course it's old Vegas and the other reviews talk about the history of the Golden Steer. But what sets this place apart is the ambiance, the service, and the old Vegas feel. 

Definitely get the table side Caesar salad the first time you go and for the full experience get one of the tableside flambé desserts. There is no chance you can be disappointed with this dining experience. You don't have to go to the strip and the prices are fair and reasonable. Give it a try.

You got a love it. So oldschool. You almost expect to see the rat pack drinking martinis and smoking inside. I don't think they've changed things since this place opened- and they better not!The food is awesome!great steaks,great salads and the martinis are amazing. I always come here when I visit Vegas. It is one of my highlights. Don't change guys! Keep it real.

Terrible place skating by on reputation alone. Everything was under seasoned, over priced, and no one seemed happy to be there. $300 for a meal I've made better at home (for 2 people btw). They didn't  cook my lobster properly. It was tough and chewy and when I sent it back they proceeded to argue that the middle was raw (not sure if that was supposed to be comforting) even though it was so overcooked on the outside I had to saw at it with a steak knife. They just assumed I wanted another one cooked (although I didn't) and the second one they brought out was barely passable. My cocktail was average and the bread was average. The $12 per person table side Cesar salad was below average and they even served people who were seated after us before us. 

There were no specials and the server was totally unhelpful despite the fact we mentioned we had never dined there and we're excited to finally be able to. They even cleared a plate that I was eating from without asking.

There was one thing that was good (crab cocktail) and it was the only reason I didn't give this place a 1 star review. I would never recommend this place to anyone. The servers look down on the clientele and they are pretty much absent if you need anything from them.

Now it doesn't look like much from the outside but looks are deceiving! Everything we ordered was delicious but very pricey. The filet mignon was cooked to perfection and their sautéed mushrooms was very good. We ordered salad too but next time I will pass on that. The bread that came with the meal was good as well.

The ambience was very old school and dark. Very romantic. It was very classy but I did see alot of people in casual wear.

I will definitely come back.

This place is awesome.  Yes I visit this place frequently and Iv'e never had a bad meal.  All their chops are great, the service is great, the atmosphere is great which makes this a great place.  I would highly recommend to any and all.

I must give the Golden Steer five stars for exceptional service and for the classic 1950's steakhouse vibe.  We patronized the Golden Steer for our wedding anniversary and were not disappointed. The food is very good.  We had the prime rib with whipped potatoes and Caesar salad.  The salad was the best Caesar I had in years, the potatoes very good.  The prime rib was good, but not great.  I don't hold it against the place as you never really know how a whole roast is texture wise all the way through.  I would have preferred a touch more seasoning but that is personal preference.  

I would highly recommend going there for the entire experience.

I had wanted to go here for a long time so I finally made it happen!!!! 

DELICIOUS    I had steak with crab meat on top it was great my steak was cooked perfectly very juicy and tender I got it paired with asparagus with just as yum!!! 

I was very happy to find a place that did cherry jubilee it was the BEST!!! Just as good as I remember I will for sure come back

Loved it! We wanted somewhere near the action but off the strip to avoid parking drama. I called for a reservation & they suggested the "Marilyn" booth. The place is old school Vegas! Leather booths and waiters in tuxedos. Our server was impressive. He told all about the history of the restaurant & showed us around to the "mob room" and other famous booths, including the Rat Pack. We ordered the seafood stuffed mushroom caps to start. Delish! Then we had the Table side Caesar salad which was truly amazing and big enough for two. I ordered lobster and my husband got a ribeye. We shared the creamed corn- hands down the best I've ever had- and a twice baked potato and bottle of wine. It wasn't cheap. I think our bill was around $225. That's what you'd get on the strip without the history and incredible service. SO happy we came to Golden Steer. We can't wait to go back and take out of town visitors.

Short and simple.
It's all about the ambiance and the atmosphere, baby! 

Like many have mentioned, this is old school Vegas. The superficiality, the glitz and glam of all those other prestigious restaurants on the strip....you can forgit-about-it!!! It's always good to go back in time and enjoy what Vegas was once all about.

Food was delicious. (Of course it was...wouldn't expect anything less from a fine establishment like this.) One really cool thing they do here is that they make certain foods in front of you. We ordered a Cesar Salad and it was a fun experience to watch them prepare it for us. Ordered steak and shrimp scampi as our entrees, we were blissfully satisfied.

Also...they lit desserts on fire??!! Seriously. It looks cool to watch but we were so full from our dinner...I couldn't stomach anymore food. Maybe I'll just come here for dessert another time?

Definitely check this place out!
The dinner rolls were very stale. The food was ok, but nothing worth the price we paid. There are other steakhouses in Vegas that I have eaten that are way better.

I'm a sucker for a restaurant with a piano bar.  This one has lots of history too.  Love the escargot, caesar salad, steaks, cocktails, servers in black tuxes, red leather high-back booths.  You got the idea.

I am so disappointed with last night's experience at Golden Steer Steakhouse.  I have been going to this restaurant for 20 years whenever we are in Vegas.  We were a party of 5 and after 1 1/2 hours the woman hostess asked us to leave because she needed our table. She was very rude and had been rude when we walked in.  Instead of asking us nicely to have an after dinner drink or coffee in the bar area so we could continue our conversation, she rudely kept standing at our table and repeating that we should leave.  The service was excellent but she spoiled the evening which included an 86 year old man who lives in Vegas.  The calimari was not freshly prepared and the bloody mary drink I ordered was not good.  What a shame to have this experience after so many years of great steaks and great service.  This woman hostess must go.

The reason this is 3 stars vs 4 is due to expectations vs reality.

This is a traditional, a la cart style steakhouse.  They are a left over from a different era and can be quite an experience to be in.  I've been in several similar restaurants (and worked in them as well in my youth) so I had a certain expectation to how it should be.

Atmosphere and ambiance was what I expected.  Service is off though.  I'm used to being introduced to the waiter or waiters for my table and the bus boy and asked if I'd been here before (if I wasn't recognized as a regular).  Instead it was very lack of warmth.  We were brought the wrong salads and when we got the right ones, they weren't brought out at the same time.  We also had to flag someone down for water and ice tea refills at least once.  Also, places of this caliber have an intermezzo service, Golden Steer does not.

The food was ok but not worth the price.  At this type of place I expect to pay high prices but I should be getting phenomenal service and top quality food and prep.  The so called "world famous ceasar salad" was not table side prep, was a small plate of a basic ceasar salad - nothing more.  The house salad a friend got was even more disappointing.  It looks like a salad I would get at a casino cafe.  Our tabled had 2 ribeyes and a top sirloin.  My wife commented that her sirlion was a bit overcooked and while good, she had had better.  The 2 ribeyes were cooked right and tasted fine but seemed to lack seasoning and didn't impress me much - for $52 bucks I can go to several other gourmet steak houses and get a superior piece of meat.  Golden steer is still trying to sell people on prime corn-fed beef at prices for what other competing places give for dried aging and grass-fed.

The power went out while we were there (not their fault).  Staff was vary accommodating because of it and reduced the check for the inconvenience (didn't even have to ask or mention anything).

We'll probably just skip this place in the future, there are better places where the food and service is better and I can get that fine dining experience.

This is a solid off-the-strip place that you can go to have a nice intimate dinner date with friends or spouse. The atmosphere imbues a classic American steakhouse. Food quality is pretty good but far from the best at their price point. You're paying more for the atmosphere that they provide. 

The service is surprisingly laid back and not as posh as one might expect. It supports a more relaxed dining experience. Ultimately, you don't need to wear a 3-piece suit to be seated.

The rating on this one was hard for me. 
I loved my steak and potato, but the service was not good and the mushrooms were weird. I guess I will stick with 3 stars, because truthfully I won't go back. 

This restaurant is pretty upscale and the food is pricey.  I live next door, so I have wanted to try it for a while.  Then I saw a groupon for $30 off, so I took it.  I took my Grandpa who is 94 and loves a good prime rib, and one of my friends, because well, I like her. 

We went pretty early because my Grandpa eats dinner at like 4 in the afternoon, so I have to usually feed him NLT 5:30. Anyway, we got there about 5:15 and it was empty except for one other couple. The decor is very nice with big red leather booths and a romantic atmosphere.  The great thing about the booths is that the tables slide out, so any size can fit!!!

Our waiter took our orders, but seemed very quiet and distant. We asked for tea with cream...no cream came. Then we asked to order wine and he started taking our food order before my friend even ordered her drink. Then there was a small spider in my wine. The waiter offered another glass, but I had drank most of this one and all the spiders siblings, so I declined.  He took it off the bill, but still had a distant demeanor. I almost felt like he didn't want us there. I kept telling my friend, you really expect so much better service from an upscale restaurant. 

I ordered the massive 22oz rib eye, because that is my fav cut and the only one in the menu.  It was huge, cooked well and flavorful. I knew this would require a Togo box. Then my friend and I decided to share a twice baked potato. This was yummy. It was crispy in the outside and creamy in the middle with bacon yumminess. 
I also ordered the sautéed mushrooms. Warning, these are not typical sautéed mushrooms. These were whole and came with a sauce over them instead of the expected slices in butter.  The weren't gross, but I didn't finish them or take then home with my steak. 

Ok, so when we were getting the check, I heard a very bubbly friendly waiter giving the "specials" to his table. Dang, why didn't we get this waiter or were told the specials?!?  I decided to mention it to the manager, because the service was just so disappointing. She told us the waiter had been there for 40 years and was loosing his eyesight and confidence. Now I felt like a jerk. I feel bad for the guy, but I'm torn, because when you order a $52 rib eye, you expect a certain amount of top service to go with it....hmmmm.  What do you think?

Returned again last Saturday.  The crabcakes were as they were the first time, as were the onion rings.  Consistent on both dishes.

This time, instead of getting the ribeye, I had the prime rib.  I prefer the ribeye.  The prime rib was solid, but not as overwhelming as I was expecting given what I had heard.  It was not crowded at all for a Saturday, but seemed to pick up around 8 pm.  You need to get to GS, old Vegas places are few and far between unfortunately....

My husband and I eat here every time we come to Vegas. This place is so enriched with Vegas history that it really takes you back to the 50s and 60s. This was one of the few places that Sammy Davis was allowed to dine at. Being a black man in Vegas during that time period was hard even for a star such as him. So he ate here and then the rest of the Rat Pack joined him. Though time has moved on, its still has the same charm and service as it did back then. It's great for a romantic night on the town or dinner with a few friends. It's hard to find this type of place in a forever changing place such as Vegas. But here it is. Besides the food is great and service is out of this world. I hope you will go and try it out for yourself. Trust me, you'll be glad you did. Be sure to ask for Franks booth. The server will fill in you in with the history that took place there. Thanks

The moment we got out of the short taxi ride from Wynn to Golden Steer - we were transported back in time, setting the clock back a few decades.  Just take a look at the exterior building, and the signage, and you'll know what I mean.  Once you enter the restaurant, you'll see the decor of an era that has come and gone, with the leather red booths, and classic bar.  If you are expecting or desire up to the date modern plating and presentation, this is not your cup of tea, unless you count 70's plating style as modern.  

However, taken as a whole, serves good food with period decor and atmosphere that just isn't replicable and if replicate just isn't genuine.   My steak was cooked to temperature, I enjoyed the huge shrimp cocktail, and the twice cooked baked potato, as well as the caesar salad.

MY FAVORITE PLACE IN LAS VEGAS !!!!!!

Do NOT let the exterior deter you from going in!! Its "Old School Vegas Baby"  LOVED IT! It truly is like a scene out of Casino VERY 60's-70's esque and the service is IMPECCIBLE!  I do not mind paying for a meal when the guests are treated like this and the food is superb and delicious indeed.  A lot of others should take note of this wonderful place!  The ambience if Old Vegas just enchanted me it just envelopes you as you walk in almost like the set of a movie.  I could care less if a celebrity was sitting there (there was and they "blended in) with the rest if us - EVERYONE was treated the same in this fine establishment.  I can see why they have been in business for so long - good old fashioned EXCELLENT food and IMPECCIBLE service.  I usually order filet mingnon (well done) not an easy task to do but they did it superbly. My steak was rich and juicy AND well done the way I ordered it.  The stuffed potatoe was GIGANTIC and very delicious too! Vegetables were fresh anad crisp and lightly butterred.  The shrimps we had for an appetizer were the size of small lobsters and mouthwatering GOOD!  LOVED then caesar salad and the way it was prepared - right at the table and FRESH and DELICIOUS! You can tell the shrimp and produce were not "sitting" in a fridge for a week either!! Beautiful and FRESH along with the rest of the meal.  No its not cheap but its sure not over priced for quality and service either! If you want cheap go to McDonalds and don't "whine" about the prices! If you want a meal thats "out-of-this-world" go here!  You will be treated like royalty.  I was very impressed that the Maitre-D waited who was kind enoug to wait with us outside while our cab came (yes I tipped him too!  It was just NICE and well deserved!).  A phenomenal experience and I am definitely coming BACK to this favorite restaurant!!  Another nice thing as I frequently travel it was nice to see diners who were dining alone were not ignored for a second - I'd be comfortable coming back here myself - oh its nice to dine with driends but I'd be just fine alone here too!! LOVE THIS PLACE!!!

Back in Vegas again. Starting to feel like my second home. What an old school classic joint. Feels like I'm in the old movie. The atmosphere was some what like a old gangster classic joint. I'm really enjoying this. Ordered me a glass of red wine and of course had to try the prime rib if beef: diamond him cut 24oz cooked rare. Not the best prime rib I've had but gotta admit on my top 5 list. I would recommend this experience to anyone. Need more joints like this back home.

This resturant is VERY over rated.  Made reservations, no one came to our table for 10 minutes.  $8 steer salad was white iceberg lettuce with sliced carrots and chick peas, 2 pieces of tomato and cucumber all mixed up and placed on a plate....very tacky, diner presentation.  The steak was good but over cooked "rare" and the potato was sent back because it had a slice in the skin and 1/4 of the potato was black.  No quality check before serving the meal.  Will not return.  Could have had a better healthier salad from a buffett for 1/8 the price.

This was on a weekday evening at dinner hour so maybe the weekend crew is better including the salad chef.

Over-the-top old school Vegas as it was meant to be! This place is fantastic in every way!! 

From the read pleather booths, to the napkin over the forearm, this place looks like it hasn't changed in 50+ years. 

We enjoyed the ambiance, the service, and the food! Oh, did I mention the food? The best steak I've had in Las Vegas! 

Thank you Golden Steer!
food is so great. i liked the french onion soup. it looked so pretty when they serve and it actually tastes better than it looks.  steaks melts in yiur mouth. its a must go to steak house in vegas.

Mmmmmmm Scampi!

I'm not sure why this place doesn't have a better rating.  I ordered the Caesars Salad (they make the dressing and salad table side) and the shrimp was deliciously juicy.  If I go back, I might try the steak, but I'll definitely be getting the Caesar salad again.  The servers make you feel like family.  They aren't pretentious, but rather inviting.  I'll definitely be coming back here.  One of my favorite vegas gems.  If you like the steakhouse at CCLV, but don't like walking through the casino while dodging little kids, this is your place.

Another great meal. . My companion had the prime rib and it was amazing.  Sides were wild rice ( great) and baked potato  (a meal in itself! )

Only criticizim i have is the jumbo shrimp cocktail was rubbery and tough,  which would mean it was probably frozen.. (i had to use the steak knife to cut it....) for 4 shrimp at $20...i expected fresh. .. 

Service was great, of course. . But. . Please, please, please. . Use fresh shrimp

I love this place. You walk in and the place reminds you of a bygone era. We sat in a large leather booth with a Dean Martin sign behind it. Apparently we sat in Dean Martin's booth. How awesome is that. So we order the caesar's salad made table side. Seriously?  It was the best salad I've ever had. I mean its just greens right?  No. You haven't eaten a caesar's salad until Bobby has made one for you at the Golden Steer. We then get our prime ribs and lyonnaise potatoes. Awesome food. The finale however stole the show. The table ordered the bananas foster and the cherries jubilee. The cherries are likely the best dessert I have ever had. And i love good dessert. If you do nothing else, order the caesar salad and finish it off with cherries jubilee. Seriously. It could all end then and you would have lived a full life. Bon apetit

Ambience!!! Steak tender, rib eye my favorite cut. Great flavor didn't need sauces. Huge baked potato and Caesar salad spot on!! Table service excellent. Actually flawless.  Interesting to note I usually get cold in restaurants but even the temperature was perfect. Ill definitely come back.

SUMMARY: My Dad and I wanted the old-school, real-deal Vegas steakhouse experience. We got it!

THE SETTING: Red leather seats, crisp tablecloths, some Sinatra drifting by in the background. Waiters in bowties dressed better than the patrons. DO NOT LET THE CHINTZY FACADE OUTSIDE FOOL YOU - this is serious business.

THE SERVICE: My father has recently had a stroke, and as such has had to seriously limit his salt intake. This was noted when the reservation was taken, and the hostess took great pains to make sure that everything was setup to accommodate his needs. If we needed water or bread or anything, a waiter was right there to provide it.

THE FOOD: First and foremost, the tableside caesar HAS to be gotten. Anchovy, raw egg, the genuine article. I do not exaggerate when I say that we ate the salad one slice of Romaine at a time, as each piece had its own unique combination of elemental flavors.

'Elemental' was the watchword for the steaks, as well; simply beef plus time for aging in a controlled environment. Cut like butter, melted in the mouth, crisp on the outside and perfect-rare inside, sitting in a pool of savory juices.

The salad and steak were so filling we split only a potato on the side, with butter and sour cream. It was good, not great, but hey, it's a potato - it can be done poorly or decently, there is no 'amazing potato'. 

The only slight miss was the creme brulee; the texture was a bit lumpish and it had clearly been kept in the fridge, then quickly blowtorched to melt sugar on top.

The coffee was excellent.

THE DRINKS: 2 martinis each, well-prepared, no complaints.

THE BILL: For four mixed drinks, two salads, two steaks, one potato, two coffees and one creme brulee, $200.

Excellent old school Vegas style steakhouse. This is a must do in Vegas! The food is to die for and the service is exceptional. Lots of great history in this place so be sure to ask the waiter to fill you in.

Enjoy!

What better place for a wolf pack of five guys than to eat steak where the Rat Pack dined?!?

Sure, it wasn't on the strip nor it didn't have any flashy decor; rather, it was dark, walls plastered with pics of famous actors and actresses from the heydays of LV, oozing with rich history. If only the walls could talk ...

As for the food, the quality of meat they prided themselves on wasn't just fluff; the 22oz Ribeye with bone in was very juicy and flavorful. The medium rare steak cut with ease, and the amount of plump fat was just right.

Like other $$$ steak houses, my heavenly creamed spinach was a la carte. Ate it all up.

I'll have to come back again to see how consistent they are. Until then, fly me to the moon ...

I am being generous when I give this place three stars.  The ambience is very posh and the service is unrivled, but the quality of the food for the price is really sub-standard.  

I ate here, after hearing about all of the great stories about this place.  The staff is quick to tell you about all of the famous people that ate there including the infamous Chicago mobster Tony "The Ant" Spilatro, but how does that make this pace special?  Ok, if your on a date it is a really nice atmosphere that kind of takes you back to the old days, but the food is a "let down"

The rib-eye is good, but for $40 bucks, my God!  Not worth it!  Trust me when I say Morton's has a much better steak for the money.  However, the appitizers are excellent.  The escargot are done very well along with the oysters, and I must say the desert was fantastic!  The Cherries Jubillee I highly recomend as well as the bannanas foster.  

So if you plan on stopping by and just getting a few appitizers along with desert with a date, this place is great.  If you plan on stopping by and getting a whole steak meal with the works, you will be dissappointed along with the two hundred dollar bill for two people!

Man... What a meal! Appetizer through dessert. Sensational!  Filet was the best I've ever had, creamed spinach and twice baked potato to die for. Creme brûlée was very unique with under tones of chocolate and coffee. Highly recommend. Ask for Scot and Bryant... They were exceptional!  Thanks for an amazing Thanksgiving dinner!

The old Vegas atmosphere is amazing. The hostess was sweet and so funny. TOM was our server and he alone made our experience amazing. We shared the steak and lobster (AMAZING). This was the best lobster that I have ever had. I would also like to mention that we had a Groupon for $60 and we experienced no issues using it. Tom was super cool about it. This is now my favorite place in Vegas. This will be my first stop every year. 

Thanks Tom & Staff for such a wonderful experience! 
Louisiana & Texas

After driving by a million times and hearing about it from a few fellow foodies, my boyfriend and I decided to go Check out the golden steer on valentines day. 

They accommodated our request for a booth and decorated the dining room and bar nicely for the holiday. We were told it was a great old Vegas steakhouse and found ourselves sitting in Joe Demaggio's booth. 

The waiter was nice enough and the service overall was okay. The famous caesar salad was pretty good and so was the lobster bisque. I enjoyed the prime rib and my boyfriend ordered the t-bone. The twice baked potato and sauteed mushrooms were to die for! The creamed spinach was ok. We loved the bananas foster dessert and overall enjoyed our experience. 

Definitely a novelty experience and enjoyable old Vegas vibe. I'm planning on taking my grandmother for her birthday as a special treat...

This is an excellent steak house.

We started with half a dozen oysters, and they were served beautifully with all the condiments that you'd expect.

We had the chateaubriand for two carved tableside.  How exactly can you go wrong?  The meat arrived just as we asked for, cooked to perfection.  The gentleman that carved the steak had clearly done this before, and he prepared and plated the food nicely, which was being served with a side of vegetables.  The veggies were also prepared perfectly.

They have a very nice wine selection, and we were able to find a bottle of zinfandel that went great with our dinner selection.

The big question you'll have to ask yourself is, is it worth the money?  If you at all flinch about spending a lot of money for oysters, meat, veggies and wine, then you do not want to come here.

If you like nostalgia, pictures of old Las Vegas on the wall, and fantastic service, this is a great place for you to consider.

So, there's the issue, what's important to you.  For me, once was probably enough, but I am glad that I went.

I had the rib eye with mushrooms and Caesar salad was the best I have ever had. The Bananas Foster ended our wonderful evening. Service was above the top Brian did our table service with the salad and dessert. Thanks for a wonderful evening.

A great restaurant to me is defined by all components of the meal from service and front of house to the last lick of the spoon..this place exceeded our expectations..I've been to all of the usually spots but if you want classy superb service and quality look no further..so much Vegas history was made in this building..the food well I'll let the pics do the talking

What an awesome evening. My man and I had heard this place was so cool and tasty...so we had to check it out. It was every bit as awesome as everyone had said. 

The hostess was very pleasant and complimented me on my dress (I told her where to get it and then we had a mini conversation on how great that store is).  We were seated at a cozy and intimate booth with lots of pics of the Rat Pack. Then we meet Fabian....and he was hilarious...with really cool hair. 

Fabian made us laugh and just made the dinner so much more delightful. He was poking fun at me for ordering an espresso while I was munching on my steak which sent me into scores of giggles (I must admit it isn't like me to have espresso before dessert...but I was dragging butt). Then he made the most amazing bananas foster table side. It was hot, sweet, tasty and gave us a good show by setting it on fire before pouring it over ice cream. 

Overall it was an amazing night and my man and I will be back for the great meat, great drinks (literally fishbowl sized martinis), and great people. So much fun!

Definitely an old school steak house and I say that in a good way!  I haven't been here since the 80s when we came here as tourists.  

A friend and I went here to enjoy a tasty steak, and that's just what we did.  Since we were there early, we had run of the place.  We took photos of the different booths where Sinatra, Elvis, Sammy Davis, Jr. and Dean Martin dined.  The hostess showed us a side room where she said Tony Spilotro would dine and she had a story about a counter where their guns were placed before they sat down.  When she said that he was there only a month before his body was found in the desert (after he was murdered, he was buried in a field in Indiana), it cast a little doubt on the authenticity of her story.  Enough of that, on to the meal.

We both ordered the 12 ounce filet that their menu refers to as "the Aristocrat of Tenderness).  I ordered a chopped green salad with Roquefort dressing.  I got the jumbo baked potato that the menu bills as "Vegas' biggest."  Finally, we each had some chocolate cake for dessert.

The bread basket was simply some sliced Italian bread--nothing special.  The steaks were wonderful.  Mine was very tender.  I ordered it black and blue and that's almost the way I got it.  It was done a bit more than I prefer.  My friend ordered his well done--he's a Brit--go figure, but he enjoyed his steak, too!

I only got butter with the baked potato and it was swimming in butter.  It was excellent!  My friend got fries which he described as chips as good as you can get in the States and as good as what he gets at home.

We both ordered the chocolate cake.  This was a bit of a disappointment.  It was a bit dry and a bit small.  There was no dollop of whipped cream to dress it up.  

Service was great.  Our server has been with the Golden Steer for years, and he was on top of everything.  Very nice dining experience in a classic Las Vegas steakhouse that has been around for years and years.

Absolutely one of our worst dining experiences. Had an early reservation at 6pm, party of four. The walls have 4 light. Sconces with small shades. The one above our booth had non frosted bulbs and a Crooked shade that lit up half our table. It took almost 10 minutes for someone to come to the table and it was one of the 30 year vets. No hello or welcome just do you want a drink. After he took or order I asked him if he could either unscrew the non frosted bulbs or straighten the shade. He looks up at it and grumbles ''I'm not doing that Move to anyother table". I've been in service for 30 years too and I've never said that to a customer. He points us to the next booth that had a reserved sign and walks away. We stand by the table not sure what to do until another waiter gestures for us to sit down at the reserved table. Having our drinks thinking ok bad start but better now when the hostess walks up to the table and loudly asks my guest if we reserved the table. I said no but could explain what happened. The old waiter was behind her. She said she new what happened and walked away. WTF then why bother us. Not an apology nothing just walks away. 
One of the main reasons for going was the table side preparations. We all ordered the Caesar salad. Another one of the 30 year vets rolls up the salad cart but stops two tables away and starts making the salad. I thought it was for a center table until he served it to us. So much for the show. 

Our food was eh at best. First the bring the entrees out in the middle of eating our salads and only offered to keep them warm under the lights. The prime rib ordered medium came out part rare, part medium rare and medium. Terribly uneven. The veal Marsala had absolutely no taste of wine and had a red sauce? The veal was tough. Only the chicken Angelo was decent. But hey they did bring out a tiny dry piece of cheese cake with a Roman candle. Too bad they didn't bring forks to share. 

Lousy service from burned out waiters, overpriced and poorly cooked food. Don't waste your money.

Came here for my birthday tonight excited because I never have been (and being a vegas native) the lady that seated us was super pleasant and helpful, even pulled out an iPad for my nephew to watch a movie at the table so he wouldn't be all over the place our server kinda sucked forgot my sisters drink, didn't check on us, had to ask some one else to take our dessert order and for the bill, the place wasn't that busy and they have a milling people waking around... Whatever, then I asked the old bartender what way to the bathroom (that's wasn't doing anything) he was a snob and yelled "YEAH YEAH YEAH THAT WAY" ... I'll probably be back because the food was SO good but come on for a $450 tab you would think they would be on it...

This place definitely lives up to the hype.  I had the 12oz filet, twice baked potato, and asparagus.  The steak was great!  The wine, great! And the cherries jubilee, AWESOME!!  The service was exceptional and really reminded me of what Las Vegas is supposed to be about.

We went here for my mothers birthday and it was a great experience. The staff were very personable and friendly. I ordered the larger filet (12oz I believe) and it was delicious. I can't say it was the best I ever had, but it's definitely up there and better than I expected. The temperature of the meat was perfect. I also shared the twice baked potato with someone and it was delicious as well. If you're looking for a nice steak dinner, this is your place.

Going through the motions. Past its Prime. Simply awful. These are but a few of the things that cross my mind when I think back to what has to be one of the worst dining experiences we have had in some time. 

Having heard of the place from my father who had eaten there some time ago and having had a requirement for Prime Rib for my sons birthday, we thought we would give the Golden Steer a try. It was memorably bad, the kind of bad that has the whole table on edge and wanting to leave. Allow me to explain..... 

From top to bottom the whole experience was terrible. 

Service: BAD and got worse: . The waiter visited our table EXACTLY 3 times in the 90 minutes we were there. Since the wine list was spotty, I went for a beer. In this day and age it is not unreasonable to ask for the selection since no drink menu was placed on our table. More to the point don't roll your eyes at me either and look put out, how hard is it to say Bud, Bud Light, et al. (Seriously no local craft beers?).  The next and biggest sin in my book was not clearing the table between courses. When you see the appetizer plates, the salad plates sitting at the table, perhaps its time to clear before you try to WEDGE the next course in.  Clear the table BEFORE you ask about desert. 

If the service was bad the food bordered on edible. It was by far some of the worst food I have had in some time. 

The appetizers: 

Toasted Ravioli: Not only was it clearly a food service product (Sysco perhaps) it was not properly fried so the interior was not completely melted. (Food temp seems to be an issue with this place too) The marinara sauce had a canned quality to it and was pretty much lifeless. 

Shrimp Cocktail: Shrimp was decent and the cocktail sauce was just okay. I also appreciate the addition of horseradish which helped pump up the cocktail sauce. 

Bread: First basket was okay, the second clearly was old. I could have taken an at bat against Madison Baumgarner with it. 

Salad/Soup

Table-side Ceasar: While they did prepare ours as part of the larger party next to us (and honestly I don't expect the poor guy doing it to make just two for us) it was dull and lifeless lacking much flavor. The croutons tasted like they were from a prior decade. 

Onion Soup: The broth was actually okay (more like an Au Jus) but again the issue of properly heating things reared its ugly head. The soup looked like it had been placed under the salamander and was never brought up to a proper temperature. The soup was just warm at service and that made the Swiss cheese clump within minutes into a curd like manner. 

Mains

Prime Rib: Not a lot to say here but it was clearly NOT slow roasted but rather quick cooked. No seasoning and it was tough and quite chewy. The Jus had no taste either. 

No desert as we were thoroughly disgusted at this point. Its clear that this place is on its last legs and perhaps needs to a featured restaurant on Kitchen Nightmares or Restaurant Impossible.  Either that our closed to put and anybody who is thinking about eating there out of their misery

Absolutely the BEAT meal I've ever had!!!  Wow!!! Steak and lobster was just amazing. Service was outstanding. The history of this place alone makes it a once in a lifetime dining experience. Few things remain from the old Vegas, I hope this place never goes away. You can sit in the same booth as Frank Sinatra, The Rat Pack, Marilyn Monroe, Clint Eastwood, John Wayne, etc etc.

The service is wonderfully old school attentive. There is so much history to this place.  The Rat Pack and Marilyn used to hang out here. The food is excellent.  Its pricing is the same as a typical class chain like Capital Grill or Del Frisco's, but the serving are huge!  You really get your money's worth here.  The small prime rib (perfectly cooked) is 17 ounces!  The waiters are quick to make suggestions for sides and appetizers.  Listen to them; they know what they are talking about.  And trust them on the wines.  They aren't trying to sell you on a $20 glass of wine.  It's extremely reasonable for what you get.  And ask about the history of the restaurant.  If you only have one night to go out for prime rib or steak in Vegas, make it at the Golden Steer!

Now I know there is a lot of competition for great steakhouses in Vegas but our meal service everything was fantastic!!!

Easy to make a Saturday night reservation that's good. We bought a $70 Groupon for $35....nice!  

Get there your like hmmm...ok... Strip mall on Sahara blvd...kind of old.

Walk in hostess with big smile offered us ride in house car instead of taxi on way back...nice!

Nice booth... Old school I felt Dean, Frank, Sammi and the boys in the air. The menu tells a great story about how they used to be regulars and you could almost envision it after their shows smokin n drinkin!

Nice wine menu not pretentious. Ordered a steak and shared with my wife with no plate charge. Nice!  

Food was great. Service awesome. I bet that waiter has worked there 25 years!! 

We had a great dinner. Skip past the outside impression and enjoy the "old school".

There is something to be said about having a dining "experience".  Servers giving you time to peruse a menu, pick a cocktail or wine, moments of pause between courses to enjoy the conversation and company of your companion(s), and never rushing to finish your table, in order to present the bill and hustle you out the door.

From the warm décor, to the attentive service, to the mouthwatering food...I enjoyed every minute of it...and it felt even more special considering the history of it.

The dry aged beef obviously reigns supreme here, but the succulent shrimp scampi accompanying my petite filet was pretty tasty, too.

Growing up in Vegas, The Golden Steer is one of a few places left of "old Vegas" that I've always wanted to try, and I'm soooo glad I finally did.

Treat yourself and go to The Golden Steer...you deserve it!

The first time I went to this steak house (2008), it was definitely 5-star. I returned in '11 and again last month '16. The stuffed mushrooms and crab on my steak were bland, the steak was good but undercooked (better than over-cooked), not outstanding...and lets face it, for over $100 pp, it should be outstanding.  The service was stuffy the last two times and it was once FUN! One of the most historical places in Vegas and on the first visit they made me feel as if I just missed an old actor or mobster.  I can get stuffy and overpriced all over over Vegas, so after two so-so tries, I'll probably give another place a shot next time.
Great steaks!  Service was quick and the food was really good.

So I am a big fan of the Rat Pack. No I don't mean Molly Ringwald, Emilio Estavez, Anthony Michael Hall, or Ally Sheedy. I'm talking about Frank, Dean, and Sammy baby. I'm talking about a time when being smooth was what it was all about and the dolls bore names like Marilyn Monroe, Judy Garland, and Shirley Maclaine. 

I am also a big fan of Vegas and despite it's several facelifts over the years the gold mine in the desert is one of my favorite places on the planet. This is where the magic happened and sometimes still does, especially when I'm rollin the dice and lady luck is kind to me. Unlike many who go for the mega-clubs, rollercoaster's, and the latest Cirque du Soleil act. I go for the nostalgic shows and spots that make Vegas . . . VEGAS BABY!!!

One such stop is the legendary Golden Steer. This place is where the rats themselves would frequent which automatically makes it a must on my to do list. So after arriving in town Niki and I got ourselves ready and hit the road. Golden Steer is located on W Sahara Avenue just off the strip. Parking is convenient and it may not look like much on the outside but just wait. When you enter it is like you have been time warped to the late 50's-early 60's. The decor has an old school class that is rarely seen anymore but strangely still sheik. The wood plank walls and red leather booths set the scene and one feels transported to a different time almost instantly after being seated. 

The staff is impeccable and informative answering every question and open to offering recommendations without making one feel uninformed. Drinks are a must and something classic is on my mind. I order a whiskey sour and as quickly as I ordered it arrives. It is absolutely perfect and if you like classic cocktails I guarantee that this is the place. When the waiter returned to take our order. To start we ordered the Caesar Salad for two prepared tableside. For our entrees Niki ordered the NY Strip and I the Prime Rib - End Cut with a Jumbo Baked Potato.

In a few short minutes a table was wheeled over and the salad was prepared. It was a show all by itself and it was clear this fellow has made this many times over the years. Let the eating begin. This is not your usual Caesar Salad by any means. The mix of vegetables makes this a more hearty Caesar but the hints of spice and anchovies is blended perfectly to taste.

After we were finished with our salads the entrees and sides arrived. Niki's strip was so tender she could cut it with a fork and my prime rib was equally tender and thick. Both cooked medium rare, juicy, and oh so delicious. This steak ranks up there at the top of my all time favorites.

The jumbo potato was simply that - jumbo. It was huge and cooked perfectly. It came with chives, sour cream, and butter. The combination as always, spectacular.

Now I know that Golden Steer is known for it's Bananas Foster prepared tableside but I am not that big a fan. So Niki and I order the cheesecake. I know it is a safe option but boy it was good. thick, creamy, with a hint of vanilla. Niki is a big fan of cheesecake and nothing gets between her and a slice especially when the quality is this superb.

So that's it folks, the shows over. When in Vegas, do what the boys used to do. Enjoy a great meal at Golden Steer and you'll be swingin like Deano himself. Since I got our attention I want to leave you with a quote from the man himself.

"I feel sorry for people who don't drink. They wake up in the morning and that's the best they're going to feel all day."

Dean Martin

Easily, Easily one of my favorite steak houses and restaurants in Las Vegas or pretty much anywhere! 

Been here since 1958 and is just a touch off the strip. The look is very old school mafia style, but NOT musky or stale smelling. Great photos of patron celebrities from the past on the walls and just an awesome wait staff that know that have made their career to be there. IT matters to them that you get great service and an great experience in coming there.

Started off with cocktails, (which were made with tremendous care), and they were spectacular! Had a Caesar salad that they prepared in front of us and was amazing! We also got the calamari with homemade marinara sauce, which was decadent! I had the bone in ribeye and my wife had the Alaskan crab legs, - that she absolutely loved and my 10 year old son had the salmon - that he said was one of the best that he has had! 

For desert we had tiramisu, which was phenomenal!  

We randomly got seated in what ended up to be Muhammed Ali's favorite booth to sit in when he visited...  Such an awesome experience! We look forward to coming here again!

- amazing food
- incredible service
- 22oz filet was off the charts
- drinks ... nice pours
- salad excellent
- sides were good. 
   - mushrooms 5 stars
   - creamed spinach and corn .... came out cold but has good flavor 

- a must for any vegas steak night

Are you looking for old school cool? Are you looking for the best steak in Vegas? Want to sit in the same booth that Frank Sinatra sat in before he'd do a show at the Sahara? Look no further than this glorious piece of Las Vegas culture and history. From the table-side prepared Caesar salad and the leather booths, everything here yells "Las Vegas Institution." 

Looking at the place from outside, may be a tad concerning...There's a ton of construction going on and the area isn't the greatest, plus the vintage bulb-illuminated sign and surrounding shops might give you pause. But don't judge this book by its cover...

We came here on a Monday night, place was busy but not at all packed. Reserved the Frank Sinatra booth (seats about five comfortably), on the phone they said, "no guarantees" but the booth was available and we got immediately seated. (You can also reserve booth's once occupied by Dean Martin, Sammy Davis Jr., John Wayne and a whole host of other pop culture luminaries.) 

This is an old-school dining experience (think Ruth's Chris or Morton's), but not so old school...They've expanded and updated the restaurant in recent years but at the same time have made sure the older part retained its charm - while not making it feel like your Grandfather's den (ok, it feels a little like Grandpa's den, but that's ok).

We came for both the food and ambience. Both were excellent. 

The meal: Our server was good-ish, not great. We told him we were 1st-timers and relatively informative, considering. We ordered a few different types of steaks - a bone-in rib eye, a filet mignon, salad, and a few sides. Then the server pretty much handed us off to his table buser after taking our order... 

Meal overall was great. Steaks were incredible, pricey, but easily the best we've had at any point in Las Vegas - and we've dined at almost every high-end steak restaurant on the strip. But...we were very taken aback by the taste of the creamed corn side. 

Apparently they prepare the cream corn old-school style, with nutmeg and some other sweeter spices - the server did not mention anything about this when we ordered the side. And there is no mention of the way it's prepared on the menu. We would have sent it back, but as I mentioned the server pretty much disappeared for the last half of our meal (after the food came). Server also did not offer to remove the side from the bill when we asked him it about (after he re-appeared) at the end of the meal and the whole side remained un-eaten.

Aside from that, Caesar salad (made table-side) was also the best we'd ever eaten. (We ate at Rao's in Caesar's Palace the following night - we also ordered a Caesar to start there too, but Rao's charged two dollars more for one that wasn't made tableside, wasn't nearly the same size and tasted like it was pre-made.)   

Steer management, your server cost you a 5 star review because of no mention (by him or on menu) about the variation/prep of the creamed corn - thankfully, no one in our party had a food allergy to nutmeg...

Worth the trip, will definitely return again. Won't order the creamed corn.

Scratching my head on some of the previous reviews, but everyone's entitled to their opinions.  We had an amazing dinner, the service was excellent.  Our server was on top of it, and it seemed like there was an entire crew assembled to take care of us.  We even chatted with the nice lady in the front after dinner for a bit and enjoyed her telling us about the history. We loved the charm of the "Old Vegas" decor, and it is truly authentic as they've been in business since 1958.  My New York Steak was incredibly flavorful, and it was the meat and the juices you tasted, not a bunch of spice you didn't expect.  Twice baked potatoes tasted like a guilty pleasure and I tried my wife's desert (chocolate creme brulee) and it was out of this world.  I find it hard to believe that you could have a bad experience here unless you're looking for a bad experience, then you'll find it even in the best of places.

oh no!  I think something has replaced my love of Gallagher's...
Love love love this place.  Driving up on it may dismay you, the outside it not cute nor inviting but once you walk in its a whole different story.  This is a true old school place where Sinatra, Sammy Davis and even OJ have eaten.  Our waiter who has been there 31 years informed us who has been in and out of this place.  The menu is classic steakhouse with prime beef that they age to perfection.  We ordered Cesar salad's for two, a rib eye 20oz, a filet mignon 12 oz, twice baked potato and mushroom's.  Every thing was perfect and delicious and huge!  Oh and for dessert we splurged on the bananas foster which was prepared table side.  This place is very pricey and you must drive to get to it.  This is also a must do on the Vegas list because of its past.  I love you GS, you will be missed and I will dream of my return sometime soon.

My husband and I have been coming here for almost 5 years - had our first date here and went this weekend to celebrate our first wedding anniversary.  How convenient there was a Groupon as well!  Well, as soon as our waiter learned we had a Groupon, he treated us like dirt.  Didn't take a drink order.  When we finally got to place one, he brought them after our salad had arrived.  Terrible service.  If you're struggling and need to partner with Groupon to get new customers, something is wrong to start with and you better make sure you do your best to get those customers back.  Food was good - but their prices are pretty steep for what you are getting.  I used to think highly of this place - old school charm, etc, but they are clearly going downhill.

We had a great dinner for my husband's 40th birthday.  We all had prime rib or filet.  Cooked perfectly!  The atmosphere was unforgettable.  If you are visiting Vegas and are looking for a classy place that is reasonable try Golden Steer

I come from a fine dining background, and was very excited to try this place after reading the reviews.  

we arrived and were promptly shown to our table.  our host was very friendly and told us a lot about the place.  who had ate there over the years, some of the darker history, ect.  a very nice start.

then we were presented with our menus....and he left with out explaining any of it.  i didn't need a 20min speal, but hearing a bit about different dishes would have been nice.  so he comes back 10 min later to take our order, we order escargot, cesar salad, prime rib and filet mignon.  he asks us if we would like any wine with dinner, and then there is a awkward moment of silence when he notices that we don't have a wine list.  he apologizes and returns with one.  not a big deal, i select a bottle  of champagne , and it is promptly brought out.

our first course arrives shortly there after, the escargot.  it comes old school style, in a dish with the little depressions for the escargot with melted butter, garlic and herbs.  the problem is that we were missing one.  it just wasn't in the dish. it vanished somewhere.  how it left the kitchen, went through our server and the captain who was serving us at the time, i do not know.  they made us another order and once again apologized.  

while this was going on, my wine glass was empty.  not just for a second.  it was empty from before our first order was served till we got the second order, around 10 min.  during this time, we had our bread filled, and our water filled by 2 different busboys, and the our server and the host stopped by, none of the noticed.  not the biggest deal in the world, but another small thing that is starting to add up.  they also did not crumb our table, which after 2 orders of escargot, was looking bad.

next up is our cesar salad.  they do it table side, with a bit of flair and some jokes, it was very well done, and one of the better salads i have had in a wile.  no problems here, it was close to flawless.  they came to clear our dishes, and once again do not crumb our table.  i also finished poring out the champagne, as we were going to get a good bottle of red with the steaks.  they did not pour for us 1 time, or notice that the bottle was empty.

on to the main course.  steak is steak right?  sadly, not so.  they used no seasoning at all on our steaks.  both were very large cuts, and looked great, but had no seasoning at all, none.  i know its all personal taste, but i was again let down.  also,  with no red wine, the steak just lacked something.  sure i could have ordered a bottle, but no one came to check on us till we were mostly finished, and i didn't want to get up to chase someone down to order one.   they cleared our plates, but once again did not crumb the table.

we were ready to get out of there, just done and a bit sad overall, when they presented us with a desert menu.  table side bananas foster.  that has to be my favorite desert of all time, and i decide to give it a shot.  

our host comes out and does a wonderful job of preparing it, and it looks and smells wonderful.  and it tastes pretty good too.  i was starting to enjoy it, when i found a huge ice chunk in my ice cream.  also they really need to switch to a better ice cream, it was not very good quality.

our bill came, but there were still desert dishes on the table, and crumbs everywhere.  not fine dining.   we paid it, and had to ask them to call us a cab.  not a huge thing once again, but everywhere else in vegas offers to do it for you.

all through out dinner, our host was very personable and funny.  they employees were funny and you could tell they enjoyed what they did.  as for the old school feel, it was wonderful.  as for the fine dining, they missed several points, and the food was average at best other than the salad.

my advice would be that if you don't mind spending a lot of money to experience a really good atmosphere with average food, you should check this out.  if you are only going to do one big dinner in Vegas though, you should check out something else.

I am a Las Vegas local. We eat out frequently. This place has the worst wait staff in town. Rude bartender. Rude waiter. With an automatic 20% gratuity, why would he give a shit. Steaks were ok. Worst creamed spinach ever. Just can't get past the rude waiter. Being a local business owner, I wonder how these people can survive in our competitive market. Don't waste your time.

Based on a Friday night 7:30 res- 3 adults:
Hate to give this spot a poor review, given it's history, but it deserves it.  This review is entirely service based.  Except from the lovely hostess who greeted us with a smile and helped us to our table, the rest of the wait staff didn't have a clue.  I say wait staff, because we never really were clear on who was our server.  It didn't matter who helped us at a given time, they all messed up an order, forgot to get something we had to flag them down to request, or simply ignored the table.  We shouldn't have to call a server over for every phase of the dining experience.  Luckily, we are all patient individuals.
The food was great, but it hurts the experience if the entrée comes well before any of the sides, as well as no wine (which was specifically ordered to come with the entrée) until after the meal is almost complete (trust me, we held out as long as we could to wait for the wine, but there simply wasn't a server that came near us for a solid 10 min). No check-in by anyone after the food came.
The icing on the cake was that when the bill came, the server explained that he comped two drinks for having to wait.  That's nice and all, but the experience still suffered, and he also had an attitude as if he was doing us a favor, which frustrated me even more.
As Vegas locals, we've been here several times.  The impression that I got is that they are relying on their reputation as an 'old school'  Vegas steakhouse to carry them.  That will work ok with the out-of-towners, but we probably don't have a reason to go any longer.

I will NEVER  return to The Golden Steer.  
 
I am a local resident, and had visited The Golden Steer only one time before, many years ago.  After my first visit I was convinced that I had eaten at one of the finest restaurants in the world.  The food, the ambiance, and the service were impeccable.  Could it be that when Thomas Wolf wrote 'You Can't Go Home Again' he was referring to restaurants, as well?
 
On Tuesday evening, December 20, I revisited The Golden Steer with my partner.    The ambiance on my first visit had been that of a Fine Steak House, elegant and tasteful.  On the Tuesday that we visited it was more akin to a Denny's in a depressed area.  Even though the room was nearly empty, we were seated next to a large corner booth occupied by what was obviously a family.  That would not have been a problem, except that shortly after our seating a young girl, about 5 or 6 years old, began singing the one partial verse of Jingle Bells that she knew - over and over.  Again, not so bad - until she started jumping up and down in the seat.  Then a "Hostess' or some female employee came over to their booth and encouraged the little girl to keep it up, sing louder; and even joined in with her for a few more rounds of the same 8 - 10 words that she knew.  I could have asked to be reseated, but I let it go.  It was the Christmas Season, after all.
 
My guest ordered a dinner salad without tomatoes.   They seemed to take forever to arrive.   They finally arrived via table side cart.  They were finished and placed on the table.  There were tomatoes on both salads.  We told the server, and he took the incorrect salad away on the cart.  Nearly 10 minutes later he returned with the salad plate in his hand, and plopped it down, very unceremoniously, in front of my guest.
 
The entrees arrived.  I had ordered Prime Rib of Beef (36 oz), baked potato, and creamed corn.  My guest had the Top Sirloin, steak fries and broccoli.  We both asked for our entree to be cooked the same way; medium to medium well.   My prime rib was overcooked - to the point of being DRY.  Fortunately, the au jus was there to make it palatable.
 
My partner's steak was closer to cremated.   There wasn't even a tinge of pink to be found in that steak.  We have both had meat that was a little too done on the outside edges, only to have it turn out to be fine as we got closer to the center.  We both kept eating, hoping for a tasty outcome.  Unfortunately, that was not the case that night.  
 
After reaching the center of the dry, tough steak, the waiter finally wandered by.  We pointed out how overcooked the meat was.   He made a production of inspecting every aspect of the half eaten steak, flashlight and all, trying desperately to find even a speck of pink.  Unable to do so, he offered to replace it, although he felt it necessary to point out that nearly half of the meat had already been eaten.  We declined his embarrassingly disingenuous offer.  He left, returning a few minutes later to say that he had spoken to the management who had graciously taken half the price of the steak off of our bill.
 
Nothing was right that night.  The corn was way too sweet.  The baked potato, while big,  was absolutely unfit to serve.  Nearly black on the bottom, it had about one half inch of dark brown, scorched flesh on the inside.  Fortunately, it was large enough that I could salvage some edible parts from the top half.  The broccoli was the opposite, both undercooked (to the point of being hard)  and COLD.  A dab of butter put on top in an attempt to make it palatable,  just sat there, unmelted, throughout the meal.
 
We asked to have the remainder of our meals wrapped to go.  I specifically mentioned wanting the au jus for my prime rib, since it was inedible without it.  I was absolutely stunned and actually embarrassed when they brought out our take home package.  Cheap Styrofoam clam-shells in a generic plastic bag!  Even Denny's has more class than to present their guests with such a cheap, inelegant farewell.  When I got home I found that the waiter had forgotten (?) to include the au jus.  My dogs appreciated The Golden Steer.  That night, they ate prime rib for the first time in their lives.
 
The prices were very high, on par with what one would expect from a steakhouse that actually serves good food.  The service was poor, and any sign of ambiance must have fled after Sinatra's last visit.  This is NOT "Old School Vegas".  This is just an establishment that  'jumped the shark' many years ago.

I don't know if it was an off night but this is just barely an okay steakhouse.  So many better choices in town that do it much better.

I have been wanting to go here literally for years, as this was my stepfather's favorite steakhouse, who passed away about 6-7 years ago.  A coupon came up on Groupon so my husband and I had a date night, and overall were pretty unenthusiastic about our meal.

Here's the good:
The ribeye on the bone is really tasty, and it comes served with au jus that makes it taste even better.  However, there's very very little discernible char, which would have made it incredible.  I also ordered it medium rare, and it came out more on the medium side.  I actually enjoyed the flavor of this steak more than the American waygu at Cut, if you can believe it. 

The service and the atmosphere is also mostly good, but the food came out so fast that we felt rushed to eat and get out.  We literally were back home in almost an hour after sitting down to eat.

Cocktails are pretty phenomenal, this might be a good place to do happy hour.  They know how to mix a drink better that I've had in most places.

The bad:
The fillet mignon was tough.  This is supposed to be the most tender meat, but the ribeye came out much more tender than this.  Also, it was ordered by my husband medium rare, but was so rare it was almost inedible in some areas.  Why he didn't send it back was beyond me.

The french onion soup came out lukewarm and not hot, and the cheese was not melted all the way.  When you took a bite, you could see the entire slice of cheese come up out of the bowl.  I implored him to send it back, but being a dork he ate it.

Caesar salad - they do the table side Caesar service and it was okay, a little overdressed and on the oily side.  There are much better places to get a quality caesar salad for more than half the price.

Garlic bread - supposed to be "famous," which reminded me of the meals I used to have at the Smoke House in Burbank, CA across from Warner Brothers Studios that had the greatest garlic bread ever.  This was prepared somewhat similar, but nowhere nearly as good.  And for $5, they give you a whopping three small pieces of it.

 So I would not recommend this steakhouse at all, and recommend instead The Flame at El Cortez, or Vic and Anthony's in the Golden Nugget for more of an old school Vegas steakhouse that is much better in the same price range or lower.  I still have to try Hugo's Cellar, which I'm told is also similar but have not made it out to try it yet.

Food was great.  We started with the Caesar salad for four, which they make table-side.  Thereafter, I had the surf and turf.  The lobster tail was huge and the filet mignon was cooked perfectly at medium.  We also ordered mushrooms, asparagus, and mashed potatoes for sides which were quite good.  A bit expensive, but every bit worth it.  The service was just right:  they left us alone when appropriate, and checked on us just enough to refill drinks, clear plates, etc.
