Amazing food, awesome staff! Knowing that the rat pack and Muhammad Ali were frequents is more than cool! Do your self a favor and get the creamed corn!
Came in for an anniversary & was blown away by the service. Specifically Thomas. Ended up making the occasion very special. Will definitely be back in the future.

Step in to the Golden Steer and out of 2012.  Welcome to the age of the Rat Pack, where people drank martinis, dressed up for dinner and ordered chateaubriand for two with table-side caesar salad. 

Leather banquettes, a staff that are pros at this and atmosphere that just won't quit.

There were 6 of us.  We walked in, had a cocktail, and were seated.  The hostess (who was great!  I wanted her to join us!) gave us the history of the restaurant and tales of Sammy Davis Jr.  She knows the history of Vegas well!

We ordered an assortment of steaks (rib eye, new york, filet mignon) and prime rib (the diamond jim cut - HUGE!), caesar salad, creamed spinach, asparagus and potatoes.  We left FULL.  

Note that the meat is cooked tru to temperature - if you say medium but are hoping for medium well... well, order medium well.

We never felt rushed.  We had a 5-Star experience all the way.

I can't wait to come back!

The atmosphere is amazing...and the service was even better. Had the Caesar salad, creamed spinach, and the 12 oz filet. LOVED the steak. Very delicious. The Caesar salad rocked too. So-so on the creamed spinach. It was a little runny and tastes sweeter than I expected. (A little salt went a long way). Not a lot of wine by the glass options. They could improve on this for sure. Only 2-3 red wine glass options. Desserts looked amazing, but I didn't order one. I would go again and order the same salad and steak. I would also order a bottle of wine vs a glass.

Amazing food. The hostess was friendly and kind. The server was professional and prompt. I had the filet. It was 5 stars in itself. Love the ambience. I'm from Vegas and this feels like part of my roots. Great Birthday dinner!

This was a clear disappointment.  The main waiter had no personality, although all of his helpers did-which was the most pleasant part of the meal. We've eaten at many steakhouses in Town in the last 25 years and the quality in the meat served was mediocre at best. When you pay almost $50 for a steak you expect to be able to cut it with a fork. We won't return.

I'm as tough of a critic as they come & have experenice with steaks all over the world. The outside may surprise you but...Go, dine, enjoy old school Vegas at its very best! Superior service, super steaks, divine caeser! Will visit every trip to Vegas! I truly have to question people's low reviews?  Our experience was truly awesome!!
Great piece of meat. I didnt know what to expect from this place but they definitely surprised me. The service was good but not great. No complaints though. I will definitely come back.

I went to Vegas this past week with my daughter and my friend and her daughter, both girls were celebrating their 21st b-day.  We made reservations at this old school old Vegas steak house and man was I IMPRESSED!  When we walked in they knew who we were, they greated us so kindly, they gave us a great table where we could see the whole restaurant.  
The hostess was so friendly she even came and sat wtih us for a bit after dinner to ask us how our experience was.  
The menu had so much good stuff on it i could not decide! 
We had steak and salads and appetizers and delicious wines from the huge wine menu. 
The waiters work as a team so you can ask any of them for whatever you need.  They were all friendly and helpfu and funny! 
I was impressed all the way and would recommend this to anyone and everyone for the old time Vegas steakhouse experience.
The prices were also reasonable and we had an amazing meal for a deal!

Came here with a large group excited for a good meal.  Very nice decor and atmosphere inside.  And that's about the only thing going for it.  The only reason I'm not giving 1 star is because of the free cheese cake offered as our wedding gift.  The prices are quite extreme for the portions provided.  The salmon was nearly $40 and was barely enough to fill you up with its tiny scoop of plain rice and 4" long salmon steak.  Service was very poor.  My wife asked for a drink refill and it was never delivered and the staff was rude and stuck-up.  Couldn't even tip low due to a unavoidable 20% tip already included.  Never again.

First the majority of the dishes were outstanding. Second the service was great. However, their signature dish the bone in rib eye had a bad taste and in fact made my guest sick that evening. I was very embarrassed. Also, the side of mushrooms was swimming in this terrible sauce.  I only ate one and no comment was made when the dish was picked up mostly uneaten.  There are many better choices in Vegas and I will choose one of  them next time.

My wife and I dined at the Golden Steer in mid July 2010 with my parents.  I did a lot of online research regarding Vegas restaurants prior to our trip and the solid reviews on Yelp really got my Dad and I excited for this place.  We both love Frank Sinatra, 'old school' vegas, and good steaks.  We figured this place would be PERFECT for us.   It's only about a $15 cab ride from The Mirage as it's located just northwest of the strip. I don't know if we hit it on a bad night or what, but this place was the absolute disappointment of the trip.

We had a 7pm reservation on a Saturday night and the place was pretty much dead.  There were about 4 people in the bar upfront which had a guy playing the piano who was pretty average.  We were in the 'front' dining room (there was another in back) and it was only us and 2 other couples.  I thought the atmosphere lacked everything the other Yelp reviewers mentioned.  There were hardly any old school pictures of the famous clientele they claimed to have served in the past.  We were in the Frank Sinatra booth and they had a prototypical picture on the wall of the Rat Pack which you could buy for about $5 anywhere.  I didn't see any authentic pictures of anyone dining there in the past and nothing was autographed.  The booths weren't anything all that special - just the old school round leather style with small inconspicuous gold plaque of who's supposed booth it was.

Our group had 1 bottle of wine, soup/salad appetizers, a new york strip steak, 2 petitie fillets, surf and turf (pettite fillet and lobster tail), and a couple of sides consisting of twice baked potatoes and broccoli and the bill came up to $325.  I had no problem dropping a bunch of money on a meal and actually expected to be into it for about $500 at this place - but I thought the prices were an absolute crime for what it was.  The steaks were good but certainly not the best I ever had.  The soup and sides paled in comparison to other high end places I've been such as Mastro's.  I'm absolutely stunned they command the prices they do for how much competition is in Vegas for this price point and how much better it is.  

The "schtick" of the place seemed to be sharing stories about who used to frequent the place, how some of their dishes came to be, and other 'humorous' stories.  All of them really lacked charm and authenticity.  Our waiter was Mexican and the hostess lady made 3 derogatory jokes about him being Mexican.  One of which was telling another table that they needed to say goodbye to him because it was the last they would see of him because Immigration was in the kitchen.  I'm not even kidding you, that actually happened.  Along with 2 other jokes along these lines.  

It's at this point that I should probably mention that I'm actual not a pretentious person nor do I have excessive dining standards - I'm certainly not a food critic.  However, paying the prices they charge for the quality of their food along with the very underwhelming atmosphere was just a complete disappointment.  I also expect a certain level of professionalism out of the staff at this price point.  

There are a number of other places my family and I would've rather dine in retrospect and we wouldn't even had to travel off the strip to do it...

This review is for 3.5 stars.

To begin, I am a fan of strip steak houses.  Yes they are overpriced but they offer that upscale, good-eats environment that almost guarantees a quality meal.  Golden Steer steers in a little different direction by staying true to its Vegas origin.  The scale of the restaurant is less than a strip steak house, however.  Though the waiters are wearing tuxedos and the prices on par, the restaurant itself is located right off Sahara in a unwelcoming shopping plaza; the bar even has machines to play blackjack.  Very Vegassy vibe.

I decided to give Golden Steer a shot because I found a Groupon and was craving a nice dinner.  I ate at the bar and was served a very nice old fashioned for $12.  I then ordered a caesar salad ($12) and a 12oz filet ($48), medium rare.  The caesar salad, though not prepared bar side like I was hoping, was a top notch salad.  Nothing too extraordinary but a top quality salad nonetheless.  The steak came without sides and was cooked all over the place.  The outside was easily medium if not well done.  The inside was perfect, but only about 70% of the steak was cooked correctly, so that was a little lackluster for a top steak house.

In all, Golden Steer is worth a go only with a coupon.  It's a nice, classy environment and different from on strip places, but I believe you can find a very similar steak (if not better) either downtown or in the suburbs for a cheaper price. albeit not back in time in old Vegas.

I've now been to Golden Steer twice. It seems like I'm being treated progressively worse. I live in the condo building next door so I try to support businesses in my neighborhood. I can honestly say I'll never be a patron at Golden Steer again. 

The first time I came to The restaurant the hostess tried to act like she couldn't seat me despite the restaurant literally being empty. There were literally 3 customers in the restaurant. I brushed it off. The servers were rude to me and practically ignored me and the prime rib was not good at all. I chalked it up to an isolated bad experience. 

I came back about 6 months later (today) and the hostess tells me there's a 1.5 hour wait. She later gets on the phone and tells another potential customer that they have space if they come now. 

I sat in the bar high tops area for about 25 minutes. Nobody brought me a menu or even acknowledged me. I literally had to go and find a server and place an order. This time I tried the ribeye. I asked for it medium rare +. They gave me a medium-medium well steak. When asked for another steak the server tried to blame it on the au jus. I eat at steakhouses weekly. Au jus had never made a steak more well done in my experience. 

As I type this I've been finished with my dinner for about 20 minutes and no one has come to offer me the check. I'm practically invisible. This is very disappointing. None of the other patrons are being treated like this. I'm the only Black patron in the restaurant. I hope this is merely a coincidence.

Wow, was very disappointed.  I ordered a strip steak, $48.00 and a side of broccoli $8.00.  NOt that I mind the prices. But I do mind when the service is terrible and the food does not come out the way I order it.  I had ordered my steak "well", the server suggested that I get it butterflied.   I agreed.  Then I had asked to have my broccoli triple steamed, I said I want it muchy!  Any way the steak came out still bleeding and not butterflied, and the broccoli, well was still crunchy!  Not complaining I just didnt eat much of my steak, and still there was no questions asked of me.

Anyway I don't recommend this place!

Couple things on most recent visit-
Calamari was surprisingly good
Waitstaff still act in a haphazard manner, had 3 different waiters during night. Some of the younger ones went into back room and I speculate were drinking. I mean whatever but its a sign this place is possibly headed downhill
My steak ordered medium came out darn near rare and then after a heat up came back leather
Finally, the bull that was out on Sahara is now in the backroom as some truck hit the pole it was on and knocked it off! A bit odd this long time iconic sign is gone and doesn't seem they will be putting it back up. Yet another sign this spot is not being run at a high end professional level.

Old Vegas atmosphere; It was neat that they identified each table by the Celebrity that dined there. (IE - John Wayne, Charles Bronson)
Table side preparation - love the banana fosters and great steak - prime cuts !
The service was outstanding !

I've been coming to Vegas for 30 years and no matter how many designer chefs start a new fancy restaurant at a new fancy hotel... this is STILL the Best Steak in town!  Excellent service and the perfect cut of steak with a nice glass of wine and Sinatra playing in the background make this the 100% Vegas experience.

The staff was amazing but the food was disappointing! My husband has wanted to come here since we moved here 23 years ago. We have always heard such great things. We had the stuffed mushrooms that were watered down with what taste like bread crumbs, shrimp cocktail that had HUGE shrimp (that was the best thing we ate) rib eye not tender or melting in our mouths, and crab legs that taste like something off a buffet, dry and tough:( It was the worst $ we have ever spent on dinner.

LOVE the table side Caesar and Cherries jubilee!! 
Been a while since I saw the Caesar down right ! 
The steak was good. 
But worth the old Vegas glory days ( reminds me of old Hollywood ambience)
WORTH the table side Caesar and Cherries Jubilee ( no crepes with this one just ice cream ;-)

Best steakhouse I've been to!  I've gone to other steakhouses on the strip, but wow, I was mind blown!  

This is a hidden gem located on Sahara between Las Vegas Blvd and the I-15.  It doesn't look like much on the outside, but you feel like you're in a mobster movie and stepped back in time when you walk in.  

This is the spot where Frank Sinatra and other famous people would go on the regular.  I've heard from others that Frank Sinatra has his own booth here.

The servers were very friendly.  They definitely made sure we were taken care of.  At least 4-5 servers would come to our table just to make sure we were okay.  

Their wine glasses are huge.  Their breads tasted like it was freshly made.  The steaks were juicy and cooked to perfection.  The whipped potatoes were light and fluffy.  We got the salad, 8 oz filet, 22 oz bone in ribeye, whipped mashed potatoes and creme brulee (with a hint of chocolate) for dessert.  Everything we tasted was purely amazing!

This is my favorite steakhouse by far.  Can't wait to go back!

Ambiance is great. You don't find many old-school restaurants like that in Vegas anymore. It's very dark and romantic as you dine with the oldies playing in the background. 

However the food is extremely over-priced and very bland. For appetizers, we ordered the Toasted Ravioli with Marinara Sauce $10, which was really good. 

For entree, they are best known for beef, so we order the Chateaubriand Bouquetiere for two with Hollandaise and Béarnaise Sauce ($55 per person) and we added on Whipped Potatoes $8 on the side. We have never tried Chateaubriand Bouquetiere before and it was boxed out on the menu, looked special and tempting, so we figured we'd give it a try.

The Chateaubriand Bouquetiere, which is a roasted beef tenderloin, was just ok. The sauces were very bland. For $55, it also came with some steams vegetables on the side (carrots, broccoli and asparagus), which were just plain steams with no seasoning at all. It was not even salted. 

Our total (for 2 people)  with 1 drink, 1 appetizer, Chateaubriand Bouquetiere for 2, and 1 side + tax & tip, came to $180.  I don't know if we just order the wrong item from the menu or they were just having an off-day?  But we went there on a Friday night, from 5-6:45 pm. We were the only table there. There was one couple that came in during our dinner, sat down, took a look at the menu, then left. Another coouple came in as we were leaving. But overall, the place was empty on a Friday night!

Old School Vegas.Fernando the waiter has been there over 30 years.he is a class act.steaks are prime and very good .very tender,with a nice charr.the may have the best baked potato ive ever had.little pricy but well worth when in vegas

Pretty damn good steakhouse and a classic. We were treated very well. The chateaubriand  was quite good. The escargot was excellent as was the French onion soup.  I had been wanting to check this place out for years and it did not disappoint.

This is one of the most over priced steak houses in town. I always drive by and have heard good things. On a spur of the moment me and the wife went here. We weren't dressed to the nines but we were a lil casual considering a steak house. I always find the staff at steakhouses to be generally awkward and overly in your face helpful. The service towards us as opposed to the other table was the exact opposite. Not sure if it's the way we looked or maybe he didn't think we had $. Either way service was a 1 star rating and food was a 3.5 star. For the price I wase expecting a lot more. Ceaser salad was great. They make it in front of you but you have to get ceaser for at least 2 people. Food was good not great. They do bananas foster flambouyed in front of you. I'd rather go to any restaurant on the strip and pay strip prices with a view then go here.
Super old school high end GEM in an old run down strip corner If you can call it that. Impeccable service. Very comfortable
Plain and simple, good ole fashion steak and sides. The most simple you can get while getting all of the savory flavors of the meat.

This place was sooooooooooo good the steak is still on mind even tho I was there a month ago and I am writing this now.  The old skool Vegas feel is there and knowing that the Rat pack ate there is awesome
One of the best meals in Vegas! Very old school layout and the staff was very attentive.

Phenomenal steak, had NY Strip 16 oz, which was done to perfection, as was the fresh asparagus as a side dish.  Definitely old school restaurant with friendly professional wait staff (i.e., not actors waiting for next gig), and lots of history.  This was a taste of the original Las Vegas, and it's nice to see something like this has survived the arrival of the facade palaces.  Frank and Dean and Sammy ate here and hung out here, and you might be seated where they once sat (we were).  Not cheap, but worth every penny.  If you want to go beyond the buffet specials and chain restaurants and simulated splendor, definitely go here.  It's a step into the past and the food was great.

I was pleasantly surprised by my dinner here. We took the recommendation of a good friend and decided to stop by the last time we were in Vegas. It was everything he had promised. 

The decor was awesome. I could totally imagine the rat pack sitting in these plush red leather booths while eating a juicy steak. The service was attentive and very friendly as well.

We each ordered the steak of our liking, me choosing my favorite, the New York. My boyfriend ordered the rib eye. Both were very good, cooked to a perfect medium rare. I ordered a side of bearnaise sauce that I also enjoyed. I love dipping steak in bearnaise. 

We also had the table side Cesar. The server wheeled his little cart over and made the dressing from scratch. It was delicious. 

This is an old hidden gem that Vegas should talk more about!

We celebrated my cousins 50th at the Golden Steer. Let's just say you will leave this establishment 5lbs heavier and pleasantly satisfied. There were 26 of us that night go dinner.

We started if off with the seafood appetizer, stuffed mushrooms and fried calamari.  All the appetizers were delicious.  We then had their Caesar salad which is made right there at your table.  I love anchovies so I was very impressed with the dressing.

I ordered the Oscar filet mignon.  All I can say is that it just melted in my mouth, it was so tender!!!! We ordered the twice baked potato, creamed spinach & steamed vegetables. I tried a little of everything, but I would definitely recommend the twice baked potato. It was crispy on the outside and creamy deliciousness on the inside. 

The cocktails were good and strong just how I like them, and the service was absolutely impeccable.

We were all so full we couldn't even order dessert, but the table next to ours ordered the banana foster and it looked amazing!!!

They brought out a dessert for my cousin with a crazy sparkler on top.

Let's just say the evening was off to an excellent start.  Next stop Intrigue Nightclub to work off those extra lbs!!!
Another old school Steak House.  Open since the 50's!  Steak was good but not in the same league as Flemings or Morton's!

Although their website shows a golden steer as their marquee, there is none.  Had the bone-in rib-eye cooked medium rare and two hours later - EXPLOSIVE diarrhea.  The clam chowder was decent, but served lukewarm, as was the steak.  The steak was full of gristle and it did not taste right, but I ate it.  Golden Corral steak would have been better!  My wife's salmon was also lukewarm.  The four other diners at our table were very satisfied with their meals.  The service was fine.  Overpriced for what one gets - will not dine there again and suggest others try any of 25 great steak establishments in Las Vegas.

The Rat Pack - The Sinatra Booth - old Vegas charm so very much missed - and great food in a charming atmosphere, The Golden Steer has it all.  As they say don't judge a book by its cover well arriving at this non descript place from the 1950's on the corner of the strip a Sahara makes you long for Yesteryear when all of Las Vegas probably looked liked this.  Truly unremarkable as you drive up and enter then you are transported back to the days Frank, Sammy, Dean, and the boys swinging in for cocktails or sitting in one of the many red booths, or in our case our party of 12 is escorted to the back dining room where we have all the privacy in the world. 

We sit and Joey our waiter begins the hey I'm not here to sell you anything extra I'm going to simply tell you what we are known for then let you make your own decision.  Those are words to live by unfortunately that's when Joey got rolling about the Shellfish platters, appetizers, etc and simply would NOT LET THE **** UP until I said listen we are all grown men, we know how to order a meal, please allow us to order whatever the hell we want in as many quantities as we want and shut the **** UP~! Again he interceded with the Have to have the Caesar salad mantra then you don't need 2 potatoes.. UGH if a guy wants to O.D. on starch allow him.  I almost replaced him but he finally got the point. 

The Good: 
Shrimp Cocktail, huge cold horseradish on side extra kick up tasty & Fresh 4 were enough for 2 persons $19.00

Escargots de Bourgogne | 16 fresh with sauce just enough to accent them without being overpowered

Alaskan King Crab Cocktail | 16 Hunks of crabmeat with same cocktail sauce that kicked up enough with butter made this a cant miss.

Caesar Salad made table side $11.00 per person was good - not spectacular just good

The Great
Rib Eye Steak, Bone-in 22oz. | $54.00 4 of these were ordered to a man stated best steak they ever had.

New York Strip 16oz. | 50$  3 of these 2 absolutely perfect charred with temperature on the button flavor off the charts  1 was sent back overcooked then when returned it looked nuked then grilled quickly it as not consumed. 

3 Filet mignon Oscars with crabmeat were all outstanding - 
1 Market price $75.00 Australian lobster tail was simply OK a bit tough

Sides: 
All excellent from the baked potatoes to the creamed spinach to the sautéed mushrooms, and twice baked potato they simply make each dish outstanding. 

The Bad - the Steak being taken back and then returned unable to be consumed was a definite mark off.  Even had to tell them Take it off the bill at the end should have been done without asking.  Service was good after old Joey stopped selling me like a car salesman; it's not our 1st time dining out.  Private room for 12 of us was fantastic and rest of staff was A Plus. 
Definitely on the repeat list when in Vegas!

From the outside, I just knew I had to eat here at some point, finally made it in.  I give it about a 3, my Aunt, who is rather persnickety, loved it, we will settle with the 4.  We went on a Tuesday and the place was just about packed by the time we left.  I knew the inside would be dated.  Their menu describes it as Turn of the Century San Francisco.  Now that I think of it, it does remind me of the back food area at the Golden Gate Casino downtown.  Lots of red and brown going on.

Contrary to the other reviews, I thought the table side Caesar was pretty good.  The french onion soup was a little on the cheesy side, but who can really complain about that.  The lobster bisque was also good but of course any lobster bisque could always use a little more lobster in my opinion.

Auntie and I had the crab and fillet, GF just had the fillet.  I had mine cooked medium and it came out just right.  The crab was okay if not a little dry.  The entrees came out fairly quickly, actually within a few minutes of finishing the soup/salad...guess I prefer this to waiting too long.

Service was fine, although I was expecting a little more.

Truly is old school. 

My husband wanted the Caesar salad because they make it table side. I am not a fan of Caesar salad dressing, so I opted out of having one. Kind of bummer because if only one person in your group orders a salad, they don't do the full service. Instead, they come with the cart, hand you the plate and the dressing on the side in a small bowl instead of mixing and tossing it for you. This is kind of a ripoff because it is still $12 for iceberg, croutons, and salad dressing. 

We ordered the prime rib and the steak and a twice baked potato to share. It was plenty of food and was prepared decent. As we wee finishing up our meals, it then became a never ending  birthday song extravaganza. Every table near us was celebrating a birthday which was a piece of dessert with a flaming firework. I hated to admit it, but it was the day before my husband's birthday. So he experienced the flaming candle thing, which was really quite cool. 

All in all, the service was attentive but a little strange with their interactions, the price was maybe a touch too high, and the clientele mixed (some in shorts/flip flops and some dressed very smartly).

On a recommendation from a cab driver I decided to venture off the strip to this classic steak house.

I ordered French Onion Soup, a twice baked potato, creamed spinach and a the smallest cut of prime rib on the menu (18oz)

The food was sub par to say the least but at least the portions were huge.

Soup came out warm not hot and the cheese was not melted properly. The soup itself was tasty but again served at the wrong temperature.

Like many of the other reviewers mentioned the meat was not delivered at the correct temperature.  I ordered medium rare I got somewhere between medium and medium well.  The Prime rib was tender and served with a soup bowl full of horseradish which was necessary because the meat had no flavor of its own.

Normally creamed spinach is my favorite part of eating at a steakhouse.  It was inedible here. IN-E-DI-BLE!!! disgusting just plain horrible, the worst I've ever had, worse than I can even describe, sour, bitter and oily.  Also it was terrible.

The twice baked potato was... nothing to write about, turly uneventful, really neither good nor bad.

At least my Bourbon tasted Okay you can't really mess up pouring Bourbon in a glass from a bottle, Oh an the staff was pleasant, I never felt rushed or ignored.  Their friendliness should be commended.
Best steak I ever had, hands down. Pricey but worth it. Expect to pay about $100 per person when the bill comes.

A secret gem just off the Las Vegas strip, this steakhouse doesn't look like much from the outside, but inside it is the essence of old Hollywood.  We had reservations and were seated quickly upon arrival.  Our waiter was quite knowledgeable which helped greatly in our meal choices.  Our friends started with the escargots which they said were "divine".  I had the poached salmon with dill cream sauce for my entree... It was spectacular!  The fish was cooked perfectly and the sauce so delicious that I wanted to lick the plate.  It also came with a side of wild rice.  My husband's 18oz prime rib was also good, but so much meat that he couldn't finish it.
Our friends had the petite and regular filet mignons.  They raved!  The side of asparagus that we shared as a table was the perfect compliment to round out the meal.

Highly recommended all around!

The quintessential Vegas steakhouse. This is a must for anyone looking for an old-school Vegas experience. The food is delicious and the service is impeccable. It's right off the strip and a quick cab ride from most hotels. I live in Vegas and it is, by far, my favorite place to come for a special occasion.

I can probably best sum my opinion of this place up by saying that I could see this restaurant on Restaurant Impossible.  I won't dwell on the service, about which many have commented (which I could actually deal with if the food were good).  I'll start with the fact that none of the wine glasses set up at our table looked clean (all had some white-ish film and mine had a little extra something on it).  That's not acceptable at the prices they charge.  The real problem is the food.  We ordered chopped green salads that were something that looked like a 7-year old could make.  The toasted ravioli may daughters ordered looked and tasted like something you can try in the aisles of Costco on Saturday morning.  The quality of our steaks wasn't bad, but they weren't very juicy.  Of the 4 steaks we ordered, only one was cooked to the medium-rare that we asked for.  The others were medium to medium-well.  I ordered steak fries that were actually seasoned well, but were undercooked and looked like slightly higher quality than something you'd find in an elementary school lunch.  We ordered bananas foster (table-side service) for dessert.  it was kind of a fun process watching it flame up.  Taste-wise, it was just a sugar-bomb with only half a banana in it.  I'll sum up with 3 notes.

1.  I went here on the recommendation of my best friend, who is a certified foodie.  However, my wife reminded me after our beyond-disappointing-for-the-price meal that my friend is Hindu and generally doesn't eat beef (so maybe he doesn't know it when beef isn't great?).

2.  My wife said the best dish was the broccoli (which was a single steamed, unseasoned crown).  To be fair, my wife really liked her apple-tini.

3.  My daughters' comment after dinner:  "The water was nice and cold."

If people like the historical significance of this place, maybe it should be converted into a museum.

Double check your bill.  Our waiter Added an additional 60.00 to our tab. "Oops...I forgot my glasses. My mistake" he said. We had an after dinner drink at the bar. A couple who had been sitting across from us and saw what happened told us that the same thing happened to another couple right after us. I guess James had aa payment due!

I loved my Saturday night dinner here! I was advised that Golden Steer is an Old School Vegas staple. It's been around since the 50s. It's a cool story. 

The boyfriend had made reservations and we were promptly seated at 8pm. It seemed to be a slow night which had me questioning the four star Yelp rating. Sure enough the place got packed right after  we were seated. 

The food was fantastic! Shrimp cocktail was very fresh with huge shrimp. Caesar salad prepared  table side including the dressing. Best Caesar I've had! I had the 10oz prime rib which was very generous in size. The creamed spinach was nothing special but the whipped mashed potatoes were fantastic! 

I even splurged with dessert, which is such a rare occasion. Cremè Brûlée was outstanding! 

Good wine and nice cocktails! We both enjoyed our drinks. 

Losing a star due to service. Our server wasn't interested in noticing that our bar drinks were empty or if we wanted another. Wasn't interested in telling us about the special of the night or the dessert menu. Due to the servers lack of interest in our experience the bf wasn't interested in leaving him a tip larger than standard 20%, but I definitely recommend this place!

WOW!!
Everyone should do a dinner here.

The GF and I made a date night out of it.
The service was fantastic, the wine selection robust and the stake we PERFECT!!

If you are from out of town, don't let the neighborhood worry you.
It's a Vegas gem to escape the strip.  Food is very good.  Service can be both overbearing and confused.  Love the history and the atmosphere.
Been in Vegas for 12 yrs., and I've been missing out all this time! Great vintage look and the service was phenomenal! For ALL you meat lovers out there, the 22oz Rib eye is a great challenge!

Absolute favorite place to eat in Las Vegas.  Been coming here for years and refreshing to see the same staff here time and time again.  Always excellent service and the prime rib is wonderful.  I always get the creamy ranch house salad, mushrooms, asparagus, garlic bread, and a prime rib as big as my head.  Never disappointed.

If you are thinking of going here, go to Vic and Anthony's instead.   I would not mind spending nearly $400 for dinner for two (1 appetizer, two steak and lobster combos and 5 drinks) if the food was amazing.   I would have been irked spending that much of the food was just good.  Because the food was mediocre, at best, I was very upset.   

I wasn't keen on the service.  But, that was no big deal.   The big deal was that the steak and lobster came out lukewarm.  And, the lobster was TOUGH.  I couldn't even cut it easily with my knife.  All this for $110 per person for the steak and lobster combo.  

The creamed spinach tasted odd.  The twice baked potato was fantastic.   

To be fair, I have to admit that I did not complain.   It was our first wedding anniversary and we were just so disappointed, we really ate what we could - left - and got a late night pizza that was amazing.

Man, this place was super average. If it wasn't for the groupon I had,  I would give it 2 stars. 
 
I paid 52 bucks for a bone-In ribeye and it was pretty lackluster. For it supposedly being 22 oz it barely filled the plate. You can get the same cut at Austin's Steakhouse in the Texas, have it be bigger, with a free sauce, and all for 10 bucks cheaper. I asked for it to be medium and it was cooked perfectly. It was also very juicy. It didn't have a lot of flavor though.

I originally wanted to order the onion rings on the menu, but the waiter let me know they were frozen and come from a box, so I just settled on the fries.The fries I got were non-crisp, starchy, non-seasoned, too thick potato spears. No salt or flavored oil or butter coating them. I had to send the over-baked, no-flavor garlic bread away. They didn't want to make the tableside caesar salad fresh at first until I asked them to. When they did make it tableside, it ended up being the most flavorful thing of my meal. The bananas fosters I got was decent, it didn't have a real good sauce though, it tasted mostly of orange. It wasn't bad, but you think of rum, brown sugar, and banana when it comes to bananas foster, not orange.

The staff was nice and accommodating. They amptly took the bread off my bill when I said I didn't like it. Another waiter quickly made sure I got my tableside salad. My drink always stayed filled and I was always checked up on.

This place seems to be living through it's glory days instead of keeping their menu up to date and competitive. For the quality of food, they are seriously over charging. Unless they put up another groupon, I won't be coming here again.

I live next door at Allure and decided to finally give this place a try. Excellent food and service - very old school Vegas formal ambiance.

I chose the lobster and petite filet which was amazing - choose the twice baked filet and French onion soup as sides!

Listed as Market Price I ended up paying a little more than expected at $100+ with tax and tip, but it was a meal well worth it.

Recommend this place and will be back for sure.

Great dinner for my birthday. I would have given them 5 stars but my filet mignon was over done. We loved the environment, the service was great. We love going to the old school Las Vegas restaurants. Golden Steer really fit the bill. We will definitely be back.

For my very first visit, I wanted to experience any vintage Las Vegas that still existed.  My research yielded the Golden Steer, and our experience was magnificent.  Away from the noise, hype, and over-priced cuisine of the strip, this classic 60s steakhouse has the décor, staff, menu, and presentation of a bygone era without being kitschy or fake.  It is completely authentic, from dark woods and red velvet chairs, to the western paintings and decor, to the low lighting and knowledgeable, friendly waiters in full tuxedos.  We enjoyed every second of it.

We intentionally ordered items prepared tableside, first Caesar salad and later Bananas Foster, so that we could be part of the experience and chat with the waiter.  He complimented our attire and my vintage necklace, saying it reminded him of a time when people knew how to  dress appropriately for dinner.  It made me smile, because that was exactly the experience we sought.  The wine list was classic and had plenty of great selections to accompany the menu.  The salad was flavorful and plentiful.  We chose escargot and Clams Casino as appetizers.  Both were delicious.  We did not soak up the escargot juices with the bread, but thinking back, I wish we had!

Our entrees were the 12oz filet and the T-bone with whipped potatoes and mushrooms as accompaniments.  I read one review that said the mushrooms were in a strange sauce, but I don't know where they got their taste buds.  They were perfectly sautéed in butter and garlic and full of flavor.  Had we not been in polite company, I am confident that my boyfriend would have chewed off what little meat remained on the bone when he finished!  

For dessert, he had the chocolate cake, I had the Bananas Foster.  The preparation and end result were mouth watering!  The chocolate cake was good, nice and fudgy, but paled in comparison to the Bananas Foster.  Knowing that my boyfriend would inevitably steal some of mine, our waiter made us an extra large portion, so I could share.  

I agree with the reviewer who noted that much of the charm and classic menu selections are lost on diners not old enough to remember the 60s.  If you want a 21st century experience, stay on the strip, but for those of us who were born in the 70s, but want to dine where Elvis, Frank, Dean, and Sammy dined, the Golden Steer hits the jackpot!
It's edible but not special any more. Not like the original Falcones. Should of just went around the block at worlds best pizza and paid $20.00 bucks for large pizza 2ltr and 8 wings .

I was not a huge fan of this place.  First of all, I realize it's an old establishment, but the neighborhood around it is not the best.  I went on a couple of friends' advice that it was the best steakhouse in Vegas.  It is not.  A friend of mine and I ate in there not terribly long ago.  I had a filet, a salad, and a glass of wine.  He had a ribeye, a salad, and a beer, and we split a baked potato.  And it was about $225.  It might be old school Vegas, but they charge some really new school prices.  The servers were curt and not very friendly.  We had to ask for water refills.  That should never happen in any restaurant, let alone one you're paying a house note to eat at.  They weren't busy, so there was really no excuse.   I've had much better steaks at Gordon Ramsay, Carnevino, Hugo's Cellar, Capital Grille, Vic & Anthony's, and others.  So, unless someone else is buying, I will not be going back here.  It was not worth the hefty, hefty price tag.  And despite their lack of business, the parking is terrible.

Place is nicely decorated... Servers wear suits but the service was horrible! (And keep in mind it was NOT busy ...Our main servers name was Brian ...But the food OMG I don't think I've ever had such disgusting food! Should have listened to our driver who advised us not to come here but instead I went off of the 4 star Yelp review and brought a few other people with me (and EVERYBODY in my party was very dissatisfied with EVERYTHING)... I had the chicken Parmesana  which was drenched in the tomato sauce yet it was very tasteless smh ...for $28 a piece of chicken (no sides includes -most sides are $9 even French fries) I really expected sooooooo much more .... Perhaps we went on a bad day but I am very disappointed with this place... Would not come back and DO NOT recommend!

What happened to this place?? Service was horrible! Food was crappy. I've come here for almost every special occasion for over ten years. I haven't been the past two years as much but it has gone down hill. So unfortunate. Two stars because the hostess at the door is awesome.

Nothing to special. They have a good steaks and a good but really pricey Caesar salad and interesting deserts. However the atmosphere, the service, the quality of food, just does not justify the prices they charge. I would have given the place 4 stars if it was more reasonably priced. But the prices they are charging it should be better all around.

Not the greatest steakhouse in the world, but a good one. I came in with mild expectations. When you first walk up to the restaurant, the decor looks real old-fashioned. You feel like you are entering the 60's version of Las Vegas. Pretty classy. I was greeted by a beautiful hostess who led me straight to my table. From there it seemed like I had two waiters for some reason checking up on me. It was kind of weird.

I end up ordering the Caesar Salad, Stuffed Seafood Mushrooms, and the Bone in Ribeye Steak.

Caesar Salad: (5/5) The salad was tossed right at the table with all the classic ingredients. The salad itself was amazing, probably the best caesar salad i've had. You could taste the subtlety of the anchovy. The croutons were also crisp, by airy. 

Stuffed Seafood Mushrooms: (2/5) I really did not like this appetizer. Usually I don't regret my orders, but this one was a big time meh. While the mushroom was cooked fine, the seafood stuffing was bland, lacked texture, and just tasted whatever. I had to force myself to finish it. Honestly, my friend makes a better version of stuffed mushrooms. 

Bone in Ribeye Steak: (4/5) The steak came out on a sizzling plate and looked like ready to beast on. The first couple bites were out of this world. It was perfectly marbled. I was ready to give the trophy as the best steak to this one. But as I beasted on the edges of the steak, the interior got a tad bit tough and was not marbled. As I got closer to the bone, the marbling came back, and I was happy again.

A Vegas classic, opened in 1958, when it was across from the now burned down El Rancho, it is the oldest steakhouse in continuous operation in town.  The walls are covered with photos of celebrities and gangsters, plus a new one of of our current mayor and her husband, the former mayor and mob lawyer.  Ask for the room in the rear, as the lighting is a little lower and the wood paneling a little richer.  We had the Shecky Green booth at the far back and I will remember to ask for it again.  Our waiter, Fabian, was just right, no hovering or "I'll be your server today" prattle, but always just a little way off when we needed him.

And the steaks were fabulous.  My rib eye covered the whole plate. Succulent and marbled with just a little fat, cooked exactly medium rare and let to rest just long enough for the juices to stay inside.  My friend's medium well filet mignon was to his liking as well.  He started with crab cakes, light and flaky and my crab cocktail was the kind that brings you back to Vegas.  My wife's oysters on the half shell were fresh and sweet, though the horseradish sauce lacked punch.

My only gripe is that the wine list is just adequate, not great.  Fabian looked at the Barolo we brought to remedy the problem skeptically, but it was big and still tannic and a great match to the meat and corkage of $20 wasn't outrageous.  Can't wait to go back with our next out of town guests.

Well, I wanted to like this place.  I was here recently with a bunch of coworkers, one who has been here many times in the past and was raving and even he said that this time, it was just "meh".

I ordered the Rib Eye, rare...it was medium/well when I got it, dry and cost $50!  Crazy!  I also tasted the asparagus side (just ok), the large baked potato (just ok) some potato/onion side (greasy), the fries (cold) and I had a tomato salad (didnt care for that at all).  What I'm saying here is, the food was WAY below par and the prices were outrageous!!  I'm only glad I didnt pay for anything.  If I had, I would have complained and sent the food back.  The food quality was a joke.  The service was fine and the atmosphere was fine as well however at the end of the day I only care about the food and it was not that great, end of story.  Would not go back.
Old school Vegas.  Great food and service BUT it's in the "hood".  Bad area of town. Atmosphere is classic old school Vegas.  Steaks are aged and primo.

Love the Decor. $17 martini a bit much. Prime rib over done, we went there last year & food was amazing, this time not true. They were busy but no excuse for poor service. It was so bad they didn't charge us for the sides. It was our 42 anniversary & all we got was a coment from hostess! Chain restaurants will give a small desert. Not cool. Next time going to steak restaurant in Orleans, better food & service. Sorry!!!

I went here for dinner last week and I just wanted to update my review by saying YES YES YES!  I still love this place for steak and escargot, and always will.  They recently won Best in Las Vegas for this year, so congrats to them!  As usual, everything from appetizers to dessert were wonderful.  

If you haven't tried this place, take the time to make a reservation and stop by.  It's more of a special occasion place because of the prices, but if you're in the mood for a great steak, being served and catered like the good ol' days with that old time atmosphere, please do stop by.

Wow did my steak suck at this place. It was tough and chewy, a complete waste of money, service was good and I would have sent my food back except I was with a large dinner party and the host of the evening had raged over the food quality.  I'll dissuade my friend next time he suggests a steak house.  I can't emphasize how bad my food was and what a disappointment it was not going to a good steak house in Vegas, I hear there are a couple of alternative places to go.

Love, love, love this place.  It is as old school Vegas as it gets.  We go here every year on our yearly Vegas trip of debauchery and it never disappoints.

Oh, and the waiter is a DeNiro impressionist.  That NEVER gets old...  

This is a must visit.
Bryant was our server he was so professional and well educated in Hospitality. I recommend this place 100% food was amazing my wife had filet with lobster and I had the chicken of angels. Amazing.

My wife and I went last night and this place is fantastic.  The atmosphere was amazing.  It is the perfect date night venue.  Our booth as cozy, the lighting was perfect and the service was attentive but non intrusive. She had the 18 oz. Prime Rib and I had the 22 oz. Ribeye and the were both perfect.  We also both had the jumbo sized baked potato as a side and it was excellent.  The only complaint we can think of is we shared a Tiramisu and it was no where near the quality of the rest of our meal.  That aside, this place is a must visit when in Las Vegas.

We went to the Golden Steer for the history and heard the food was pretty good too.  Was so disappointed.  It says proper dress attire required and people came in in sweat shirts and blue jeans.  There were several people yelling on their cell phones which if they had any manners they would have taken it outside or at the very least, management would have asked them to take it outside.  The food was normal steakhouse food, but we won't go back.  $220 later, I'll go back to Del fresco's anyway.  I never mind the price if the whole experience is worth it.  VERY disappointed.
We made a reservation for the Dean Martin table and could not have been happier to sit in history..our waiter was very helpful and the food was amazing..great place for a 40 year wedding anniversary.
Fabulous old Vegas vibe. The seafood platter appetizer is the best we've ever had anywhere! Henry is a very attentive waiter and we always request him! Making a reservation for tonight!

This was indeed a wonderful meal.  The wait staff was professional and helpful in suggestions and the food was most flavorful.  We had the prime rib and it was excellent.  A nice glass of wine to go with it and I am only sorry we were too full to try the desserts

Fantastic!  The Ceaser Salad and Creamed Corn were both the best I have ever had.

Atmosphere and Steaks are amazing.

salads watery and cheap, our broccoli was raw.waiter spilled water on me and dropped plates clearing the table.  prime rib was tasteless.  had to navigate a sea of bums in parking lot. worst fine dining experience i ever had.

We come here every trip to Vegas. I make a reservation so I don't have to cool my heels in the bar. Party of seven this visit and everyone said they would definitely come back. Our check average was $75 per person plus drinks.

The ribeye was the most delicious steak I've had this year.  The caesar salad (made tableside) was tangy enough but my brother took points off for the fact that they made it in a plastic (not wooden) bowl.  I'm with him on that.  My only other major gripe is the wine list has a lot of room for improvement.  Avoid the twice-baked potato: very dry.  But it's fun and the waiters are great.

This place was great.  Made a reservation for 12 guys during a bachelor party this past weekend and we were seated immediately upon arrival.  We had our own private room in the back that had been used by mobsters and celebrities alike.  Our waiter even took some time to explain the history of the restaurant which was actually quite interesting.  The food was excellent--a bit pricey but you get what you pay for!  If you're looking for a nice restaurant, away from the bright lights of the city, then this is definitely the place for you.  I'd certainly go back.

This is a classic, 'old school' steakhouse, which opened in 1958. It retains it's charm, elegance and class today.

Leather booths, low lights and courteous servers make for an outstanding experience. 

The food ? Oh, my, it is simply delicious ! I had a NY Strip steak (about $40) with a chopped salad and it was one of the most mouth watering steaks I have ever eaten.

Many of the tables are marked with entertainment stars names, we sat at Dean Martin's table (next to Sammy Davis Jr's table).

A great place ! Try it the next time you are in Las Vegas !

Sure, you could go to one of the steakhouses on the Strip that have been decorated to look like an old-school steakhouse... but for the same money, why not GO to an old-school steakhouse?

The Golden Steer looks like a total dive on the outside, but inside it's the room that time forgot. Everything looks exactly like it would have back when the Rat Pack was said to be among the Steer's clientele. Service is equally old-school - your glasses will never be empty and every crumb quickly swept.

The menu is equally traditional - steaks, creamed spinach, etc. It's cooked to order and tasty.

We've gone here to celebrate signing big deals, but we've also just gone to get a great steak. It's worth the cab ride.

I dipped my crablegs into what I thought was a bowl of butter. A LOT, of butter, cus I fudgin' looooove butter. Turned out to be a bowl of horseradish. After I got over the initial chokefest, one of the guys at the table dared me to eat a spoonful of horseradish for $100. 

I ate the entire bowl. Just because. That's about the time I hit rock bottom.

There was steak & other food involved. 3.5 stars.

We have lived in Las Vegas for 40 years, the Golden Steer was always on our "to-do" list but there are so-o-o many great restaurants in Las Vegas it took us a while to eat here. 

What a dissapointment, my t-bone was tough, you could go down the block a bit to Palace Station's Broiler & get a better steak and a much better deal. My husbands's prime rib was just okay, a better one at half the cost can be had at Jerry's Nugget.
Since this was a "bucket list" thing to do we were let down.

Everything was a la carte, I mean $12.00 for a small plate of Caesar's salad, really??? We don't mind having an expensive meal if it is worth it, save your money...it is not worth it.

Great service to start the evening, ordered the Caesar  salad, garlic bread,rib eye,band twice baked potato.  The salad bread and potato were outstanding.  The steak however severely disappointed, after talking with the waiter and being assured and recommended medium, it came out somewhere between medium well and well done.  The manager came by to see how everything was right after they brought the food out. Between then and the end of the meal our waiter was no where in sight, another waiter eventually came by after the table was cleared to offer us dessert then the check.  Overall i'v had better cooked steaks and better service at establishments offering 8$ locals specials.   The only thing salvaging two stars is how good the sale bread and potato were.

Wanted to try a different steakhouse than the usual ones we eat at when traveling to vegas. I found this one on yelp and decided to try it out today dec. 16, 2016. All I can say is the reviews are all right on the money. This place is awesome! We had the assorted seafood sish appetizer which consisted of wvery sea crustation and it was soooo good! Then we had the rib eye 22oz bone in. And brah let me tell you, 22ounces is all meat, they dont consider the bone weight. Soft, juicy, no need add salt or peepa. Oh and the moscow mule, da best I ever had. Cream corn, sauted mushroom, brah dis place you gotta try out. Sorry had no room in stomach fo desert. Next time.

Long on my Vegas bucket list, Golden Steer finally found me entering her hallowed halls for a recent monumental birthday celebration. The place conjures up everything that 'old Vegas' inspires in the minds of anyone of a certain age who is old enough to appreciate the Rat Pack era, but young enough to still be able to stay up as late as Sinatra did back in the day. Red leather banquettes, gold chandeliers, dim lighting, servers dressed at least as well as the patrons...it's all there. We were seated at Betty Grable's booth and promptly greeted by a somewhat aloof server. Our wine and calamari appetizer arrived quickly and we summoned our steaks and sides soon thereafter. We had ordered the signature tableside Caesar salad, but it was unfortunately forgotten. Once our steaks arrived we reminded our server of the forgotten salad and he halfheartedly acknowledged his gaffe. The hostess then arrived and told us that the salad would be compliments of the house. All appreciated. The steaks and salad were very good and prepared precisely as ordered, but once the bill arrived the salad was included. We reminded the hostess of the error and she quickly took care of it. (I wish she was waiting our table that night) Our server returned for the check, but without much to say other than the minimal niceties. All in all we definitely enjoyed our meal, but I have a feeling another server would have taken it to another level. I'd definitely visit again, but perhaps only when our particular server was enjoying a somewhat-deserved night off.

This is one of my favorite spots anywhere.  This is the type of place my dad would have liked. In fact I do believe he came here back in the day. This is off the strip here in Las Vegas and not many tourists go here. But the locals sure do. It's never real busy during the week but you do need to make reservations. 

When you walk in here you feel like you just stepped in to the 1960's-1970's. It's really cool. And the respect to the dinning experience is what it is all about here. Unlike the rest of Las Vegas they care about service. A lot of the wait staff have been here for a long time and are just not working here until they finish school or make it in acting or something. They care about your experience. 

Oh....and the food is off the charts. The steaks are amazing. The seafood tower is terrific. The Caesar salad is old school in the fact that they do it the RIGHT way. At the table with all the ingredients that are suppose to be in a Caesar salad. Like a raw egg and anchovies. 

If you come to Vegas. Come here!

What a surprise! My husband and I accidentally stumbled upon this restaurant while driving back to the Turnberry.
Dark and cozy, great bar, best Caesar salad, made table side, wonderful wine list, attentive service, great steak, over-sized baked potato, what more could one want? ( garlic bread could have been better).

Will make this a must place to eat every time we visit family in Lad Vegas.

Don't let the ugly strip mall it is located in scare you off. The restaurant is well worth visiting and returning to again and again.

If you are looking for a good slab of meat at an affordable price, this is a pretty consistent place to eat, especially with a large dinner group. Not fancy or frilly but decent steaks in huge proportions with a family casual setting. Dont order the chicken or any seafood, this place is a red meat zone! Would you order sushi at Katz's deli? Far better than any outback, lonestar or boulder creek or any other chain steakhouse, but certainly no Lugers, Mortons or Delmonico.
If you are old enough to remember the RatPack, this is the place for great steaks.  Atmosphere is genuine old school. Steaks were great. The staff was even better.

I'd been there before with a large group (April 2009), and it was great. Some of the same group were there for this Sunday April 8th 2012 dinner. We were a large group, and the restaurant claimed it was "no problem". I'm sure we were all aware that we were going to be hit with an automatic 'large group' gratuity fee, and we were totally willing and able to pay it. While ordering, I inquired of our server (T#m) if it was possible to get "separate bills". He said that it would "all be divided at the end". OK. So we order. Some people's meals were much more expensive than others. The food was stellar. End of the meal, and the bill comes. One big bill. For everybody. When T#m was asked why our bills were not separated we were told: "We don't do that here". Which is BS, as I'd had it done before. We proceeded to spend about ONE HOUR trying to figure out who was supposed to pay for what. It COMPLETELY KILLED the good meal we had just consumed. In retrospect I believe he was just worried that we were trying to snake our way out of paying the automatic 'large group' gratuity. I normally over-tip as it is, but on this occasion I think I was sure to pay not a penny over what was required - purely out of spite. Oh yeah, he also uttered this gem: "This isn't Denny's". Huh, well Denny's has it all over the Golden Steer, as they automatically separate your bills! I don't think the Maitre D' was too impressed with T#m either, as he was openly mocking him whilst serving the appetizers. 
 It was doubly embarrassing for me personally as I had a couple of first-timers with me along for the experience. They were APPALLED at what occurred. Not a good experience, and a pricey one too!
 I'd consider going again if I knew that T#m didn't work there anymore.

I thought it would be cool to check out an old steakhouse establishment.  Apparently the Rat Pack came all the time in the old days.

I had their ribeye and twice backed potatoes.  Very good steak.  Juicy and just the right amount of fat.  Twice backed potatoes was ok.  Should have gotten the standard baked potatoes.

Definitely on the pricier side.  It was a good one time experience.

The Golden Steer has been around since 1958 and if only those wood-paneled walls could talk. Oh those red tufted leather booths, white table cloths and oil paintings on the walls are retro and ageless at the same time. I had the $40 prime rib and since it was early in the evening I requested an end cut and got it. I kid you not folks ... It has been several years since I ate that slice of beefy heaven and I can still remember the delirious waves of culinary ecstasy that each bite sent swirling through my body.

No, it is not cheap, but its not the most expensive steak house in town either. Their baked potatoes are legendary for their size and flavor, so at least one person in your party should order that. Service is classy and attentive but not in your face. Their bar is gorgeous and glamorous too!

If you would enjoy traveling to another era for a couple of hours, then do try this place. As other reviewers have said, it is not all that inviting from the outside, but give it a chance and all of your senses will thank you.

We really wanted to like this place but we won't be back.  We celebrated my husbands birthday.  We usually go to Mortons but had a groupon for the Golden Steer.  Our server was ok, a little strange and not overly friendly.  Got the feeling he was over us when we mentioned groupon.  My husand had the Ceasear salad which was a good portion and homemade.  My onion soup was warm and not hot but flavor was good.  I had the smallest prime rib they had which was 18oz and ridiculously large.  My husband had the petite filet.  Both were just ok.  Definitely not the "Finest Steaks in Las Vegas" as they promote here.  The Lyonnaise potatoes were gross.  Smothered in onoions on top so you can't even see it's a potato dish.  Prices are high-not worth it

Fantastic! Like other reviews say, totally a step back into classic Las Vegas! Service was excellent! Joey, our waiter, certainly looked the part and took fabulous care of us! Too many exclamation points? We ate early and sat at the Sinatra booth - pretty cool. The whole decor, the leather galore, the photos from back in the day, the music...all added to the experience. Every staff member we encountered was excellent. First though is that we ordered (and ate) too much. We started with two excellent crab cakes. Then the table side caesar salad which was perfectly balanced - lemon, garlic, anchovy, etc. My wife had the filet Oscar (which she loved) and I had the bone-in ribeye (which was the best steak I have ever had). Dry aged, prime beef cooked perfectly (rare). It was absolutely delicious! For sides, we had the twice baked potato and the creamed spinach. The potato was good, but the least good of everything. I thought the spinach was excellent, my wife wasn't crazy about it. They use a touch of nutmeg (which I love and is probably what turned my wife off). I would definitely go back and highly recommend it to anyone that loves a great steak. We wouldn't have known about this classic had it not been for Groupon. With a couple of glasses of wine, our tab was $230'ish - the Groupon knocked $60 off, and it was well worth the price!

Anyone following my reviews knows how much I like good service, grand surprises and interesting anything.  The Golden Steer meets all of my criteria in such a huge way that there won't be enough room for me to sing its praises.  The strip can be so repetitive and boring.  Let's face it, sometimes over stimulation can become mundane.  The brain becomes numbed with flashing lights, bustier clad waitresses and $50 tiny bites decorated with balsamic squiggles.  Surprise me.  Take me to the Steer.

Walking in initially you'll say to yourself:  "...What the Hell have I done?"  (the place looks like a ranch house meets steak joint meets speakeasy - it's very old and in no way resembles the black lacquer, track-lit Wolfgang Emeril place you ate last night).  However,  if you keep an open mind, suspend your strip-sanitized expectations and really get in to it, you'll have the time of your life here.  For God's sake, people - dress up for the occasion.  Pay the proper respect to one of the last standing restaurants of old Vegas.  If it was good enough for Frank, Ava and Sammy to dress up for, it's good enough for you.  

The staff fawns over the well heeled.  They,  themselves in tuxedos, bend over backward to make certain that you are comfortable, that you have what you need; they make recommendations, they give compliments, they prepare old school Caesar salad table side. The water & wine glasses are never empty.  It 's like being in an old black and white movie - they are just THAT courteous.  

The food? It's not cheap, folks.  However, food is expensive in Vegas.  At the Steer, you'll be rewarded with huge, quality portions.  I am picky when it comes to red meat.  Very picky.  I like it so rare it might just be considered raw.  Few places ever get it right.  The Steer was right on the money.  My prime rib was seasoned beautifully, cooked perfectly, presented on dishes that probably have not been updated for 20+ years (to this last part I say, 'hooray'!  I'm so weary of the super slick scene in Vegas). My whipped potatoes were rich, creamy and delicious.  Don't miss the Caesar salad mentioned earlier.  They still use the raw egg and you can't beat the texture or the flavor of this authentic method.  My companion's NY steak was, again, a perfect medium-rare.  He commented that it was the best he'd had in recent memory.  Since the two of us eat out, literally, all over the U.S., Europe and central Mexico that's saying something.  I can't speak to the dessert tray as we were too stuffed for anything but coffee.  We sampled the coffee with seven liquors.  We made the mistake of ordering two and here comes my only criticism:  they are SO strong that they taste like gasoline smells.  Coupled with the bottle of wine we had, it was too much booze for one fabulous night.  I'd skip this staff recommended beverage and just have a standard cup.

When it was time to bid farewell, jump quickly back into a cab (the Steer isn't in the greatest area of town - be advised), and head back to the masses we were actually a little sad.  Everything back on the strip seemed too bright, too phony somehow.  How an old joint sporting a plaster cow outside can be glamorous is beyond me, but it is.  Eating at the Steer you'll feel like you've not only had a meal, but an adventure.  You'll also  feel a little smug having had the moxie to actually leave the strip to dine where American legends have knocked back a few together.

This place is such a gem! My boyfriend heard that the place had been around for a while, so we decided to try it. Boy, was that one of the best decisions he's made! It definitely doesn't look fancy on the outside but the inside is decorated with old celebrity photos, cozy, and extremely impressive! We ordered fresh oysters, and they were pretty good. Beware: their horseradish is no joke! It was good, but strong and unexpected. We also got the Caesar salad, which is prepared table side for two. Their steak is one of the best in town! They claim it's been the best since the 1950s, and they live up to the expectations. For a stand alone steak, with no fancy butters or seasonings, I recommend the golden steer. It is a great place for a date night, or close friends in an intimate environment. For dessert I reccommend the creme brûlée...it's chocolate!

The highlight of my trip to Vegas! Both times. I don't understand all these comments about how bad the service was. The first time we came here we were mislead by a guidebook saying this place was tacky and not great but was frequented by the likes of Elvis, John Wayne, Frank Sinatra, Dean Martin, Sammy Davis Jr and on and on. We pictured a diner that served diner type flat top fried steaks. When we walked in with t-shirts and jeans only to be greeted by a man in a tuxedo we knew we couldn't have been more wrong. They treated us great, so great we didn't even care the bill was over $200 for just the 2 of us. This was like stepping back into classy pre-strip Vegas, maybe that's why people aren't impressed.......

Had a great mean at the Golden Steer!  Steaks are awesome and the sides were lots of great choices.  The best part of the meal was the ambiance, old Vegas at its finest.  I believe this place was opened in the '50's and a hot spot for the 'Rat Pack' Elvis and many others.

My friend and I went to go check out the oldest steakhouse in Vegas, we wanted to see where the Rat Pack frequented and many other celebrities.  The service at best was mediocre, the setting and ambiance was nice. I ordered a coke which was flat,  a garden salad that was drenched in ranch, a filet mignon medium rare that was tasty and cooked to perfection, creamed spinach that was so soupy and runny it was disgusting, whipped potatoes that tasted like box potatoes, the "famous" garlic bread was burned and tasted like there wasn't even a hint of garlic on it, for dessert cherries jubilee that ended up like a soupy mess..the bill was $246.67 of course before tip. I have had much better service and food at other steakhouses.. I should've stuck with Anthony's at the M. They never do me wrong.

This is the first time I have ever written a review on any type of establishment or service, but I felt so strongly about the way our bill was presented I had to voice my displeasure to all that will see. Went to the Golden Steer steakhouse with a close friend, We are both born and raised in Las Vegas and remember coming to this restaurant many many years ago. It was one of the few fancy steakhouses back in the day. Wanted to enjoy a nice meal in a old school higher end not OUTBACK steakhouse since it had been forever and thought we may get much better quality and service then one of the chains we go to all the time Morton's, Del Frisco's  Flemings etc.....looking forward to their table side caesar salad since not too many places offer that these days. The captain or waiter not sure of his title was polite enough but not very engaging. A little too aloof for that job only my opinion The salad was decent not the best table side Caesar but okay. We both ordered the shrimp scampi which was good. Shrimp were decent size and the scampi sauce was delicious!  The service was not so great or the caliber you would expect from a restaurant that markets itself a certain way along with the prices it charges. We had to request additional water along with bread several times. They kept forgetting, and it wasn't busy at all. That in itself doesn't turn me off from coming back or recommending a restaurant, everyone has an off night, but what does and why I am writing this is the way the bill was presented. The Captain/waiter brought over a portable credit card reader swiped my card and then stood there and pointed out the tip choices. He got his 20% which would be the norm that I tip but it was out of the pressure of him standing over us. While he would have received a tip, the service wasn't very attentive it was mediocre at best my feeling 15% tip would have been fair.  I have never ever been presented a bill in this manner and would never expect this at a so called higher end steak house. For that I will never patronize nor recommend this establishment to anyone. Management really needs to revisit this practice. It screams very low class

5 stars for this place, it was my first time here and I found it on yelp. It had high reviews and the pictures of the food looked amazingly good. I made a reservation on open table and when we got there we were greeted and seated right away. The booths were old school, lightning was dim the place just had a great vibe.

Our waiter Scot was very nice and helpful with the wine and dinner menu. We got the ribeye which took up the whole plate you gotta have an appetite to finish the whole thing. Then the lobster and filet mignon was to die for, I love my steak a little pink on the inside and they cooked it perfect. Lobster tail was huge I couldn't even finish it all. The twiced baked potatoe was filling it's enough for 4 people, the mushrooms were so good I wasn't a fan of the asparagus it didn't have too much flavor. We got a bottle of wine which topped off the whole meal I definitely would recommend trying this place it's pricey but we'll worth it.

For a place that bandies about the "Rat Pack" as being former patrons, I expected a bit more.  The decor is definitely what you'd expect from a "steak and martinis" type of establishment.  However, it's located in a run-down strip mall and we found the dining room virtually empty at 9:00 on a Thursday night.  This gave the place feel more like a seedy airport lounge than somewhere I would have found Frank Sinatra or Dean Martin.

As for the food, the pride that this restaurant has in its steaks is not misplaced.  The beef is really good, if overpriced.  The 14 oz. New York Strip that I had was a whopping $40.  Even the chicken entrees were $27-28.  I know it's expensive to eat in Vegas; but this seemed excessive.  Mind you, this is coming from someone who dines out regularly in San Francisco.  Anyway, the beef was the only thing that impressed.  The salad looked like it was from a bag and the sides of mashed potatoes and creamed spinach were nothing short of baby food.  The mixed seafood platter that we started with was stocked with king crab that was still frozen and cocktail sauce that could have come from Red Lobster.

The service was very attentive and our server was quite personable.  He even comped a couple of desserts when he found out we had some birthdays at the table.

If you're a carnivore with a fat wallet and little love for ambiance, then this place is for you.  As for me, I don't think I'll be coming back the next time I'm in Vegas.

Wow.... just wow... This place has the absolute best steaks that I have ever had. Went here with my wife along with my sister and her husband. Their treat I am thankful to say, lol. 

The decor here is an absolute must experience for anyone living in Las Vegas, at least once. The outside of this place is extremely misleading from what actually lays on the inside. But once inside, it is classic Vegas. They have a table for the Rat Pack, a table used by Elvis, the works. The servers are friendly and we got to meet the waiter who'd been there for 30 years. The servers and the decor were all incredible in every aspect and I could find no fault whatsoever.

Now for the food... Everything is a la carte, so expect to spend a huge amount of cash. We got the stuffed mushrooms as an appetizer and they were quite yummy, but the portion was a bit small for a group of four. I got the massive Diamond Jim Cut Prime Rib which is 24 oz... I thought my stomach would explode from the size of that sucker! I got it medium rare and it was perfect, I will dream of that steak for years and years to come. Everyone else at my table got something different, wife got the veal parmigiana while my sister and her husband both got steaks, but we all agreed at the high quality.  We also ordered one of the potatoes but with my steak I never could get around to trying it =(

We went to this restaurant looking for the nostalgia of the Vegas of old. It is definitely old fashioned and that part was cool, minus the fact that it was really dirty. The food itself left a little something to be desired. Our steaks were very salty, the lobster was very rubbery, and the creme brûlée was literally cold, chunky and brown. The waiter(Tom/Tommy) was going to get us a wine list, never did. He barely even came back to the table. He wasn't very personable and waited over my shoulder as I entered in a tip and also pointed at the receipt showing me which gratuity examples there were for him. I found it to be very rude and was really disappointed. We came to see a restaurant from a lost time, we saw it, but everything else was a miss, we will not be going back.

There's always something interesting to see in Las Vegas.  The night BF and I went to Golden Steer, we saw a man pick up a streetwalker in the parking lot.  The interesting part was that, the street walker was an old man and he was wearing pink leotard and pink tutu.  I can't be certain but I think he also had a pink bow on his head. The whole incident took about 7 minutes and we couldn't stop staring!  When the lovely "couple" drove away, we decided it was safe to get out of our car and walked towards the restaurant.

From the outside, the restaurant doesn't look like much but inside, it was really nice.  I'm a sucker for ambiance and I really liked the old school and classy décor.  All the servers were dressed in formal uniform and they were very attentive.

To start with, we shared a bowl of Lobster Bisque.  It wasn't bad but it tasted slightly different from all other lobster bisque I've had before.  It was smooth and creamy but on the heavier side and somehow it tasted a little tart (kind of like sour cream). 

For entrée, BF had Petite Filet Mignon and I had Lil Cut Prime Rib.  We both ordered medium and both meat came out perfect.  The Prime Rib was HUGE and it was delicious especially with the freshly grated horseradish.  As for the Filet Mignon, BF said he's had tastier piece for much less at other restaurants. I believe him; the man always gets Filet Mignon at any restaurant that has one on menu.  

Overall, I'd rate this place 3.5 stars.  I enjoyed the Prime Rib but the Lobster Bisque, not so much.  Also, we saw two of their staff hanging out and taking cigarette break in front of the restaurant - one before dinner and another after dinner.  I didn't expect that for this type of restaurant.

Had the bone in Ribeye, twice baked potato, mushrooms and caesar salad, it was all perfect, and delicious, if you like steak, this is the place, great service also. Frank, marilyn, sammy, and others could not have been wrong.

I've lived here since 1965. As a kid I remember driving past this restaurant and it's business sign with the steer in the center. Last night I ate at the Golden Steer for the first time with my husband. OMG this is my favorite place to eat now! I can't believe it I've been missing out on this local gem. The old Las Vegas ambience and impeccable table service is incredible! We were treated like royalty and the food was out of this world. We had the Cesar salad and Banana Foster prepared side table - great presentation! Love, love, love this place!!! 5 stars for sure!

What a gem! This old style steak house. The outside may confuse some yet as soon as you enter the second set of doors you will know you made the right choice.

The service is outstanding. Very friendly attentive. Dressed like wait staff of yester year. What a pleasure! 

The food was cooked to order. My Hubs ordered the Tbone and Australian Lobster Tail. He could not stop raving about the Lobster tail. 

This is our new go to spot for date night.
